title: ~게다가 [gedaga] (Moreover, besides)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to introduce an additional point or detail that strengthens the previous statement.
long_explanation: `~게다가 [gedaga]` is a conjunctive adverb in Korean. It is used to add further information or details to a previously mentioned point, similar to 'moreover' or 'besides' in English. It implies that the subsequent information is an additional detail rather than a completely separate point.

examples.kr: 그 카페는 커피 맛이 아주 좋고, 게다가 분위기도 좋아서 자주 가요.
examples.romaji: Geu kape-neun keopi masi aju jo-go, gedaga bunwigi-do jo-a-seo ja-ju ga-yo.
examples.en: I often go to that cafe because not only is the coffee really good, but the atmosphere is also nice.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 오고, 게다가 추워서 나가기 싫어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-eun bi-ga o-go, gedaga chu-wo-seo na-ga-gi si-reo-yo.
examples.en: Today, it's raining and, besides, it's cold so I don't want to go out.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 참 좋고, 게다가 똑똑해서 사람들이 많이 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Geu-neun seonggyeogi cham jo-go, gedaga ttokttok-hae-seo saram-deul-i ma-ni jo-a-hae-yo.
examples.en: He has a very good personality and, moreover, he is smart, so many people like him.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 음식이 맛있고, 게다가 가격도 저렴해서 자주 찾아가요.
examples.romaji: I sikdang-eun eumsik-i masit-go, gedaga gyeog-do jeo-ryeom-hae-seo ja-ju cha-ja-ga-yo.
examples.en: The food at this restaurant is delicious and, in addition, the prices are cheap, so I visit often.

title: ~거니와 [geoniwa] (And, besides)
short_explanation: Used to add an additional reason or explanation, equivalent to 'and' or 'besides' in English, though it is more literary.
long_explanation: `~거니와 [geoniwa]` is a conjunctive particle used in Korean to connect two clauses, providing an extra reason or detail. It is similar in function to 'and' or 'besides' in English. This construction is more formal or literary and is less common in everyday speech.

examples.kr: 이것은 비싸거니와 내가 원하는 모양도 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun bissageoniwa naega wonhaneun moyang-do anieyo.
examples.en: This is not only expensive but also not the style I want.

examples.kr: 나는 책 읽거니와 영화도 좋아해서 주말마다 항상 바빠요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaek ilkkeoniwa yeonghwado joahaseo jumalmada hangsang bappayo.
examples.en: I not only enjoy reading books but also like movies, so I'm always busy on weekends.

examples.kr: 이 상품은 품질이 낮거니와 서비스도 엉망이에요.
examples.romaji: I sangpumeun pumjili najgeoniwa seobiseudo eongmang-ieyo.
examples.en: This product is of poor quality and, besides, the service is also a mess.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 재미있거니와 감동적이에요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun jaemiitgeoniwa gamdongjieyo.
examples.en: That movie is not only entertaining but also moving.

title: ~것만은 [geot man-eun] (But / At least)
short_explanation: This construction is used to emphasize that one particular aspect is an exception, often contrasting with expectations.
long_explanation: The `~것만은` construction in Korean is used to highlight that despite other circumstances, one specific aspect does not follow the expected result. It is often used in a contrasting or contradictory context to stress that, if nothing else, this one thing is different.

examples.kr: 그녀는 공부를 열심히 했는데, 학교에서 점수가 좋지 않은 것만은 이해할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gongbureul yeolsimhi haetneunde, hakgyoeseo jeomsuga jotji anheun geotman-eun ihaehal su eopsseoyo.
examples.en: She studied hard, but I can't understand why her scores at school aren't good.

examples.kr: 어젯밤에 잠을 많이 잤는데, 아직도 피곤한 것만은 이해하기 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Eojjeotbame jameul manhi jassneunde, ajikdo pigonhan geotman-eun ihaehagi eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: I slept a lot last night, but I still can't understand why I'm tired.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 열심히 노력했는데, 게임에서 지는 것만은 너무 아쉬워요.
examples.romaji: Uri timi yeolsimhi noryeokhaetneunde, geimeseo jineun geotman-eun neomu ashuwoyo.
examples.en: Our team worked hard, but it's such a shame that we lost the game.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 운동을 했는데, 체중이 늘어난 것만은 실망스러워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil undongeul haetneunde, chejungi neureonan geotman-eun silmangseureowoyo.
examples.en: I exercised every day, but I'm disappointed that my weight increased.

title: ~과/와 같이 [gwa/wa gachi] (Like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express a comparison, similarity, or analogy, equivalent to 'like' or 'as if' in English.
long_explanation: `~과/와 같이 [gwa/wa gachi]` is an expression used in Korean to draw a comparison or analogy, showing that one thing is similar to another. It is equivalent to saying 'like' or 'as if' in English and helps in visualizing or emphasizing the resemblance between two things.

examples.kr: 지난 주말은 봄과 같이 따뜻했어요. 하지만 이번 주말은 겨울과 같이 너무 추웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan jumal-eun bomgwa gachi ttatteushaess-eoyo. Hajiman ibeon jumal-eun gyeoulgwa gachi neomu chuweoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Last weekend was warm like spring, but this weekend was as cold as winter.

examples.kr: 그 그림은 사진과 같이 생생해 보여요, 그래서 그가 대단한 화가라는 것을 알 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu geurim-eun sajingwa gachi saengsaenghae boyeoyo, geuraeseo geuga daedanhan hwaga-raneun geos-eul al su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: That painting is vivid like a photograph, so you can tell that he is a great artist.

examples.kr: 오늘은 여름과 같이 더웠어요, 그래서 아이스크림을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-eun yeoleumgwa gachi deowoss-eoyo, geulaeseo aiseukeulim-eul meogeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Today was hot like summer, so I ate ice cream.

examples.kr: 독서는 운동과 같이, 마음을 건강하게 해주는 활동이에요.
examples.romaji: Dogseo-neun undonggwa gachi, ma-eum-eul geonganghage haejuneun hwaldong-ieyo.
examples.en: Reading is like exercise; it's an activity that keeps the mind healthy.

title: ~나마저 [namajeo] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to express surprise or emphasis, indicating that even the unexpected subject or object is included.
long_explanation: `~나마저 [namajeo]` is a postpositional particle in Korean that emphasizes an unexpected inclusion, similar to 'even' in English. It highlights that the subject or object in question surpasses normal expectations.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에서 가장 어려운 수업도 쉽게 이해하는데, 이 수업 나마저 이해하는 걸 보니 그녀는 정말 대단해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoeseo gajang eoryeoun sueobdo swipge ihaehaneunde, i sueob namajeo ihaehaneun geol boni geunyeoneun jeongmal daedanhaeyo.
examples.en: She easily understands even the hardest classes at school, so seeing her grasp this subject, she's truly amazing.

examples.kr: 나는 보통 친구들과 잘 지내는데, 그 친구 나마저 저를 싫어하는 것 같아서 상처받았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun botong chingudeulgwa jal jinaende, geu chingu namajeo jeoreul silheohaneun geot gataseo sangcheobadasseoyo.
examples.en: I usually get along well with my friends, but I was hurt because even that friend seems to dislike me.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들은 다 반대했지만, 그는 한 사람이라도 지지하는 중요성을 알았어요. 그런데 그 사람 나마저 반대하자 기분이 나빴어요.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeureun da bandaehaetjiman, geuneun han saramirado jijihaneun jungyoseongeul arasseoyo. Geureonde geu saram namajeo bandaehaja gibuni nappasseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone else opposed it, but he recognized the importance of having even one supporter. However, when even that person opposed, he felt bad.

examples.kr: 책상 위에 있는 모든 물건들을 봤는데, 그 물건 나마저 찾지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeksang wie inneun modeun mulgeondeureul bwatneunde, geu mulgeon namajeo chatji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I looked at every single item on the desk, but I couldn't even find that item.

title: ~뿐만 아니라 [ppunman anira] (Not only... but also)
short_explanation: Used to express 'not only... but also' by adding additional, related information.
long_explanation: `~뿐만 아니라 [ppunman anira]` is used in Korean to add extra information, indicating that something applies not only in one aspect but also in another. It serves to emphasize that a subject or event encompasses multiple qualities or characteristics.

examples.kr: 그녀는 중국어뿐만 아니라 일본어도 유창하게 할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun junggugppunman anira ilboneodo yuchanghage hal su itsseumnida.
examples.en: She can not only speak Chinese but also speak Japanese fluently.

examples.kr: 나는 공부뿐만 아니라 운동도 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gongbuppunman anira undongdo joahaeyo.
examples.en: I not only like studying but also enjoy exercising.

examples.kr: 이 상품은 가격이 저렴할 뿐만 아니라 품질도 뛰어나요.
examples.romaji: I sangpumeun gakyeogi jeoryeomhal ppunman anira pumjildo ttwieonayo.
examples.en: This product is not only affordable but also of high quality.

examples.kr: 그는 한국어뿐만 아니라 영어도 유창하게 구사해서 통역으로 일하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangugeoppunman anira yeong-eodo yuchanghage gusahaeseo tongyeogeuro ilhago isseoyo.
examples.en: He can not only speak Korean fluently but also speaks fluent English, so he works as an interpreter.

title: ~더니 [deoni] (After, and then)
short_explanation: Used to connect two clauses, indicating that the second clause follows after the first.
long_explanation: `~더니` is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two clauses or actions, showing that the second event or state was realized after experiencing the first. It is often used in narratives or personal experiences to indicate a change or consequence.

examples.kr: 저는 이것을 먹었더니 맛이 진짜 변했어요. 그래서 다른 음식을 찾아 마시기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun igeoseul meogeosseodeoni, masi jinjja byeonhaesseoyo. Geuraeseo dareun eumsigeul chaja masigi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: After I ate this, the taste really changed. So, I decided to look for another food.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 전화했더니 그녀는 휴가 중이라 전화를 못 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege jeonhwahaesseodeoni, geunyeoneun hyuga jungira jeonhwareul mot badasseoyo.
examples.en: After I called her, it turned out she was on vacation and couldn't answer the phone.

examples.kr: 서점에 갔더니 내가 원하는 책은 이미 다 팔렸어요. 그래서 다른 서점에서 찾아야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Seojeome gassdeoni, naega wonhaneun chaegeneun imi da pallyeosseoyo. Geuraeseo dareun seojeomeseo chajaya haesseoyo.
examples.en: After I went to the bookstore, the book I wanted was already sold out. So, I had to look in another bookstore.

examples.kr: 피자집에 갔더니 주문하려던 피자는 이미 전부 소진되었어요. 이런 경우는 처음이에요.
examples.romaji: Pijajibe gassdeoni, jumunharyeodeon pijaneun imi jeonbu sojindoeeosseoyo. Ireon gyeonguneun cheoeumieyo.
examples.en: After I went to the pizza place, the pizza I intended to order was already completely sold out. This was a first for me.

title: ~이든지 ~든지 [ideunji deunji] (Whether… or)
short_explanation: Used to present multiple alternatives, similar to 'whether... or' in English.
long_explanation: `~이든지 ~든지 [ideunji deunji]` is used in Korean to list alternative options or possibilities, conveying indifference about which one is chosen. It is often used in both interrogative sentences and statements to present choices.

examples.kr: 당신이 커피를 좋아하든지, 차를 좋아하든지, 이 카페에서는 모두를 만족시킬 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i keopi-reul joh-ahadeunji, cha-reul joh-ahadeunji, i kape-eseoneun modu-reul manjogshil su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether you like coffee or tea, this cafe can satisfy everyone.

examples.kr: 아침에 일찍 나가든지, 저녁에 늦게 돌아오든지, 매일 한 시간 동안 만나기로 약속해요.
examples.romaji: Achim-e iljjik nagadeunji, jeonyeoge neutge dol-aodeunji, maeil han shigan dong-an mannagiro yaksokhaeyo.
examples.en: Whether you leave early in the morning or come back late in the evening, we promise to meet for an hour every day.

examples.kr: 햄버거를 좋아하든지, 피자를 좋아하든지, 이 식당은 모든 음식을 제공할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hambaegoreul joh-ahadeunji, pijareul joh-ahadeunji, i sikdang-eun modeun eumsigeul jegonghal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether you like hamburgers or pizza, this restaurant can serve all kinds of food.

examples.kr: 당신이 평일에 여행 가든지, 주말에 가든지, 무관하게 편하게 여행을 즐기세요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i pyeongil-e yeohaeng gadeunji, jumal-e gadeunji, mugwanhage pyeonhage yeohaeng-eul jeulgiseyo.
examples.en: Whether you travel on weekdays or on weekends, enjoy your trip comfortably without any worries.

title: ~임에 틀림없다 [ime tteollimeopda] (Without a doubt)
short_explanation: Used to express certainty, meaning 'without a doubt' or 'it's certain that...'.
long_explanation: `~임에 틀림없다 [ime tteollimeopda]` is used in Korean to express a high degree of certainty about a situation or outcome. It emphasizes that there is no doubt about the assertion and is often used in formal or written contexts.

examples.kr: 그의 출연이 성공적이었음에 틀림없지만, 그의 재능은 더욱 뛰어남에 틀림없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui chulyeoni seonggongjeogieosseum-e tteullim-eobsjiman, geuui jaeneung-eun ttwieonam-e tteullim-eobseoyo.
examples.en: While it's too early to say that his performance was successful, there is no doubt that his talent is outstanding.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 이길 확률이 높으니, 우리가 이겨낼 것임에 틀림없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri timi igil hwagru-i nop-euni, uriga igyeonael geosim-e tteullim-eobseoyo.
examples.en: Since our team's chance of winning is high, there's no doubt that we will win.

examples.kr: 그는 비록 다른 사람들에게 비판받더라도, 그의 선택이 옳았음에 틀림없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun birok dareun saramdeulege bipanbadeudorado, geuui seontaegi olhassum-e tteullim-eobseoyo.
examples.en: Even if he is criticized by others, there's no doubt that his decision was correct.

examples.kr: 관측소의 예보에 따르면, 내일 비가 올 것임에 틀림없어요.
examples.romaji: Gwanchukso-ui yebo-e ttareumyeon, naeil biga ol geosim-e tteullim-eobseoyo.
examples.en: According to the weather station's forecast, it will without a doubt rain tomorrow.

title: ~쩌면 [jjeomyeon] (Maybe, perhaps)
short_explanation: Used to express possibility or probability; 'maybe', 'perhaps'.
long_explanation: '~쩌면 [jjeomyeon]' is an adverb that expresses the speaker's uncertainty about a situation. It is usually placed at the beginning of a sentence to suggest that something might be the case. It can be translated as 'maybe' or 'perhaps' in English.

examples.kr: 쩌면 그는 진심으로 당신을 사랑했을지도 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon geuneun jinsimeuro dangsineul saranghaess-euljido mollayo.
examples.en: Perhaps he really loved you.

examples.kr: 쩌면 이 갈등은 해결될 수도 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon i galdungeun haegyeoldoel sudo isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Maybe this conflict could be resolved.

examples.kr: 쩌면 그 계획이 성공할 수 있을지도 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon geu gyehoegi seonggonghal su isseuljido mollayo.
examples.en: Perhaps that plan could succeed.

examples.kr: 쩌면 이번 시험은 제일 어려울 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon ibeon siheomeun jeil eoryeoul sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: This exam might be the most difficult.

title: ~치고는 [chigoneun] (For, considering)
short_explanation: Expresses the meaning of 'for' or 'considering' when reality is better or worse than expected.
long_explanation: '~치고는 [chigoneun]' is a postpositional expression used to compare a situation with expectations. It conveys that, considering the condition or status of something, the outcome is surprising or different from what one might expect.

examples.kr: 그가 어린애 치고는 너무 많은 책을 읽어서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga eorin ae chigoneun neomu manheun chaegeul ilgeoseo nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I was surprised that he, for a young child, reads so many books.

examples.kr: 팀장 치고는 너무 책임감이 없어서 모두가 기분이 나빴어요.
examples.romaji: Timjang chigoneun neomu chaegimgami eopseoseo moduga gibuni nappeosseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone was upset because he, for a team leader, lacked responsibility.

examples.kr: 첫날 치고는 너무 많은 고객들이 왔고, 우리는 정말로 바빴어요.
examples.romaji: Cheotnal chigoneun neomu manheun gogaekdeuli wassgo, urineun jeongmallo babbeosseoyo.
examples.en: On the first day, too many customers came and we were really busy.

examples.kr: 그녀는 몸이 작은 편인데, 작은 체격 치고는 꽤 힘세다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun momi jakgeun pyeoninde, jageun chegyeok chigoneun kkwae himseda.
examples.en: She may be small, but for her small stature, she is quite strong.

title: ~커녕 [keonyeong] (Far from, let alone)
short_explanation: Used to show that the actual reality is far from the expected outcome.
long_explanation: '~커녕 [keonyeong]' is used to emphasize that not only did the expected result not occur, but something even less occurred instead. It is similar to saying 'far from' or 'let alone' in English.

examples.kr: 계획은 잘 하겠다고 했는데, 시작하기도 커녕 준비조차 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Gyehoegeun jal hagetdago haessneunde, sijakhagido keonyeong, junbijochado mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: He said he would plan well, but far from even starting, he couldn’t prepare at all.

examples.kr: 약속 시간에 늦지 않을 거라고 생각했는데, 일찍 오기도 커녕 늦게 와버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Yaksok sigane neujji anheul georago saenggakhaessneunde, iljjik ogido keonyeong, neutge waboryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought he wouldn’t be late, but far from coming early, he arrived late.

examples.kr: 공부하러 도서관에 갔는데, 독서는 커녕 졸다가 하루가 다 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhareo doseogwan-e gassneunde, dokseoneun keonyeong joldaga haruga da gasseoyo.
examples.en: I came to the library to study, but far from reading, I ended up dozing off and the whole day passed.

examples.kr: 세일에 간다고 기대했지만, 싸게 살 생각은 커녕 더 비싸게 살게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Seire gandago gidaehaetjiman, ssage sal saenggageun keonyeong, deo bissage salge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was expecting a sale, but far from buying cheap, I ended up spending more.

title: ~판에 [pane] (In the midst of)
short_explanation: ~판에 [pane] is used to express that something happens in the midst of a particular situation or event.
long_explanation: '판에 [pane]' is a grammatical pattern used to indicate that an action occurs during or in the midst of another event. Although its literal translation might seem odd, it is best understood as 'in the midst of' or 'during' and is often found in formal or written Korean.

examples.kr: 학교가 시작된 판에 새로운 학생이 입학하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoga sijakdoen pane saeroun haksaengi ibhakhaessseubnida.
examples.en: A new student was admitted in the midst of the school term beginning.

examples.kr: 회사가 오늘부터 폐업하게 되는 판에 저는 새로운 직장을 찾고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Hoesaga oneulbuteo pyeop-eophage doeneun pane jeoneun saeroun jikjangeul chatgo issseubnida.
examples.en: I am looking for a new job in the midst of the company closing down starting today.

examples.kr: 주요 사업을 준비하고 있는 판에 회사의 주식이 급등하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Juyo saeobeul junbihago issneun pane hoesaui jusigi geupdeunghaessseubnida.
examples.en: In the midst of preparing for a major project, the company's stock skyrocketed.

examples.kr: 시험공부를 하는 판에 친구들이 놀러왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomgongbureul haneun pane chingudeuli nolleowassseubnida.
examples.en: My friends came to hang out while I was studying for an exam.

title: ~하건마는 [hageonmaneun] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or opposition; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~하건마는 [hageonmaneun]' is a conjunction used to contrast two clauses. It shows that even though one thing is true, another conflicting fact or situation follows.

examples.kr: 난 그래픽 디자인을 공부하건마는 컴퓨터를 잘 못 다뤄서 디자인 프로그램 사용이 어려운 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Nan geuraepik dijaineul gongbuhageonmaneun keompyuteoreul jal mot darwoseo dijain peurogeuraem sayongi eoryeoun geot gata.
examples.en: I study graphic design, but I'm not good at handling computers, so I find design programs difficult to use.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아서 산책하려고 했건마는 갑자기 비가 와서 산책할 수 없었어.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johaseo sancaekharyeogo haetgeonmaneun gabjagi biga waseo sancaekhal su eopseosseo.
examples.en: The weather was nice today so I planned to take a walk, but suddenly it rained and I couldn’t go.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 잘하고 싶건마는 단어 외우기가 너무 어려워서 매일 공부해도 잘 생각나지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul jalhago sipgeonmaneun daneo oewoogiga neomu eoryeowoseo maeil gongbuhadaedo jal saenggaknaji anhayo.
examples.en: I want to be good at Korean, but memorizing words is so difficult that even with daily study, I can’t remember them well.

examples.kr: 친구가 나에게 생일 선물을 주기로 했건마는, 그는 선물을 잊어버려서 아무것도 주지 않았어.
examples.romaji: Chinguga naege saengil seonmureul jugiro haetgeonmaneun, geuneun seonmureul ijeobeoryeoseo amugeotdo juji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend promised to give me a birthday present, but he forgot and ended up giving me nothing.

title: ~하더라도 [hadeorado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if', 'even though', or 'despite'.
long_explanation: '~하더라도 [hadeorado]' is a grammatical construction used to express a hypothetical or contrastive situation—essentially meaning 'even if' or 'even though'. It is used with all types of verbs to emphasize that the outcome remains unchanged despite the condition.

examples.kr: 비가 오더라도 우산을 가져가지 않을 거예요, 제가 우산을 싫어해서요.
examples.romaji: Biga odeorado usaneul gajyeogaji anheul geoyeyo, jaega usaneul silheohaseyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I won’t take an umbrella because I don’t like them.

examples.kr: 피곤하더라도 공부를 계속해야 해요, 시험이 곧 있어서요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhadeorado, gongbureul gyesokhaeya haeyo, siheomi got itsseoseoyo.
examples.en: Even if I'm tired, I have to keep studying because the exam is soon.

examples.kr: 일찍 일어나야 하더라도 항상 운동을 해야 돼요, 건강을 위해서요.
examples.romaji: Ichik ireonaya hadeorado hangsang undongeul hae dwaeyo, geongang-eul wihaseyo.
examples.en: Even if I have to get up early, I always exercise for my health.

examples.kr: 시간이 없더라도 저는 부지런히 한국어를 계속 공부해야 합니다, 한국어에 관심이 많아서요.
examples.romaji: Sigani eopseorado jeoneun buzireonhi hangugeoreul gyesok gongbuhaeya hamnida, hangugeo-e gwansimi manh-aseo.
examples.en: Even if I don’t have time, I must continue studying Korean diligently because I’m very interested in it.

title: ~하든지 말든지 [hadeunji maldeunji] (Whether... or not)
short_explanation: Used to convey 'whether... or not'.
long_explanation: '~하든지 말든지 [hadeunji maldeunji]' is a compound ending that expresses indifference toward the outcome regardless of which choice is made. It implies that the result remains unchanged.

examples.kr: 그 사람이 좋아하든지 말든지 우리는 계획대로 진행하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarami joahadeunji maldeunji urineun gyehoekdaero jinhaenghagesseoyo.
examples.en: Whether that person likes it or not, we will proceed according to plan.

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 오든지 말든지 우리는 계속해서 산책할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Oneul biga odeunji maldeunji urineun gyesokhaeseo sancaekhal gyeongiraeyo.
examples.en: Whether or not it rains today, we plan to keep taking walks.

examples.kr: 네가 참여하든지 말든지 이 파티는 계속될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Nega chamyeohadeunji maldeunji i patineun gyesokdoel geosida.
examples.en: Whether you participate or not, this party will continue.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 사랑하든지 말든지 나는 계속해서 그녀를 사랑할 거야.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naleul salanghadeunji maldeunji naneun gyesoghaeseo geunyeoreul salanghalgeoya.
examples.en: Whether she loves me or not, I will continue to love her.

title: ~하려니와 [haryeoniwa] (Trying to, but)
short_explanation: Used to express a situation where one tries to do something but encounters an obstacle.
long_explanation: '~하려니와 [haryeoniwa]' is used to show that while one is attempting to do something, an unexpected difficulty or issue prevents it from happening. It can be translated as 'trying to, but' or 'want to, but' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘은 친구들과 함께 영화를 보러 가려니와, 갑자기 날씨가 너무 안 좋아져서 계획이 실패했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun chingudeulgwa hamkke yeonghwareul boreo garyeoniwa, gapjagi nalssiga neomu an johajyeoseo gyehoegi silpaehaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was trying to go watch a movie with my friends today, but the weather suddenly got so bad that our plan failed.

examples.kr: 좀 더 다양한 맛의 음식을 만들어 보려니와, 요리 실력이 부족해서 잘 되지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jom deo dayanghan matsui eumsigeul mandeureo boryeoniwa, yori silryeogi bujokhaeseo jal doeji anhayo.
examples.en: I tried to make food with a variety of flavors, but it didn’t turn out well because my cooking skills are lacking.

examples.kr: 빨리 잠자려니와, 많은 생각들이 머리를 스쳐 지나가서 잠에 들지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Ppalli jamjaryeoniwa, manheun saenggakdeuli meorireul seuchyeo jinagaseo jame deulji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to fall asleep quickly, but I couldn’t because many thoughts kept running through my mind.

examples.kr: 운동을 시작하려니와, 집에 있느라 시간을 못 내어서 아직 시작하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul sijakharyeoniwa, jibe issneura siganeul mot naeoseo ajik sijakhaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to start exercising, but I couldn’t find the time because I was stuck at home, so I haven’t started yet.

title: ~하여간 [hayaegane] (Anyway, anyhow)
short_explanation: Used to express that one will proceed regardless of difficulties or obstacles.
long_explanation: '~하여간 [hayaegane]' is used in Korean to show a determined resolve or to express that, regardless of any obstacles or factors, one will do something. It is similar in meaning to 'anyway' or 'anyhow' in English.

examples.kr: 시험을 준비하지 않았지만, 노력하여간 시험을 통과하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul junbihaji anhjiman, noryeoghayaegane siheomeul tonggwaharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Although I didn't prepare for the exam, I will try to pass it anyhow.

examples.kr: 비록 경제적으로 어려운 상황이지만, 아끼려하여간 학비를 모아야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Birok gyeongjejeogeuro eoryeoun sanghwangijiman, akkyeo sayonghayaegane hakbireul moaya hamnida.
examples.en: Even though the financial situation is difficult, I must save for my tuition fees anyway.

examples.kr: 힘들어도, 꾸준히 하여간 그 목표를 달성할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Himdeureodo, kkuduni hayaegane geu mokpyoreul dalssengal su isseul geosimnida.
examples.en: Even if it’s hard, if you persist anyhow, you will be able to achieve that goal.

examples.kr: 많은 자금이 필요하지만, 아껴 사용하여간 꿈을 이뤄낼 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Manheun jagumi pil-yohajiman, akkyeo sayonghayaegane kkumeul irwonaelsu isseul geosimnida.
examples.en: Though a lot of money is required, by spending frugally anyway, you will be able to fulfill your dream.

title: ~하여야만 [hayeoyaman] (Only when)
short_explanation: Indicates that a certain condition must be satisfied for something else to happen.
long_explanation: '~하여야만 [hayeoyaman]' is used when a specific condition or criteria must be met for an outcome to occur. It is equivalent to 'only when' in English and stresses that without this condition, the result is unattainable.

examples.kr: 일찍 기상하여야만 출근시간에 도착할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Iljjik gisanghayeoyaman chulgooksigane dochakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I can only arrive at work on time if I get up early.

examples.kr: 당신의 사정을 받아들여주신 의사와 상의하여야만 수술 계획을 변경할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsineui sajeangeul badadeulyeojusin uisawa sangyihayeoyaman susul gyehoekul byeongyeokhal su isseubnida.
examples.en: Only when you consult with the doctor who understood your circumstances can you change the surgery plan.

examples.kr: 고정적인 수입이 있어야만 주택대출을 받을 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gojeongjeogin suipi isseoyaman jutakdaechurul badul su isseubnida.
examples.en: Only when you have a regular income can you get a housing loan.

examples.kr: 훈련을 잘 따라하여야만 시험에 합격할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hunryeone jal ttarahayeoyaman siheome hapgyeokhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Only when you follow the training well can you pass the exam.

title: ~해야겠다 [haeyagetda] (Should, ought to)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's intention or determination to do something in the future.
long_explanation: '~해야겠다 [haeyagetda]' is a pattern used to express necessity or determination for a future action. It indicates that the speaker has decided that something should be done.

examples.kr: 이제 늦었으니까 집에 가야겠다.
examples.romaji: Ije neujeosseunikka jibe gayagetda.
examples.en: Now that it's late, I should go home.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhaeyagetda.
examples.en: I have an exam tomorrow, so I should study tonight.

examples.kr: 체중이 계속 증가하고 있어서 운동을 시작해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Chejungi gyesok jeunggahago isseoseo undongeul sijakhaeyagetda.
examples.en: My weight continues to increase, so I should start exercising.

examples.kr: 오래동안 연락하지 않아서 친구에게 전화해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Oraedongan yeollakaji anhaseo chinguege jeonhwahaeyagetda.
examples.en: I haven't been in touch for a long time, so I should call my friend.

title: ~에 근거하여 [e geungeohayeo] (Based on)
short_explanation: Expresses the notion 'based on', 'according to', or 'in accordance with'.
long_explanation: ~에 근거하여 [e geungeohayeo] is used to indicate that a statement, action, or conclusion is derived from a particular source such as data, rules, or authoritative information.

examples.kr: 데이터에 근거하여, 이 제품이 가장 잘 팔렸습니다.
examples.romaji: Deiteo-e geungeohayeo, i jepumeun gajang jal pallyeotsseumnida.
examples.en: Based on the data, this product sold the best.

examples.kr: 법에 근거하여, 그는 잘못되었다는 것이 증명되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Beop-e geungeohayeo, geuneun jalmosdwaessdaneun geosi jeungmyeongdwaetseumnida.
examples.en: Based on the law, it was proven that he was wrong.

examples.kr: 과학적 연구에 근거하여, 지구 온난화는 심각한 문제입니다.
examples.romaji: Gwahakjeok yeongu-e geungeohayeo, jigu onnanhwaneun simgakhan munje-ibnida.
examples.en: Based on scientific research, global warming is a serious problem.

examples.kr: 그녀의 후기에 근거하여, 이 식당은 맛이 좋지 않다고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui hugi-e geungeohayeo, i sikdangeun mas-i joji anhdago hamnida.
examples.en: Based on her review, this restaurant doesn't taste good.

title: ~에 비추어 볼 때 [e bichueo bol ttae] (In comparison to)
short_explanation: Used to express comparison; 'in comparison to' or 'compared to'.
long_explanation: '~에 비추어 볼 때 [e bichueo bol ttae]' is used to compare one subject or factor with another, often to assert a judgment or highlight a contrast.

examples.kr: 우리나라에 비추어 볼 때 미국의 문화는 매우 다릅니다.
examples.romaji: Urinarae bichueo bol ttae miguk-ui munhwa-neun ma-eu dareumnida.
examples.en: Compared to our country, American culture is very different.

examples.kr: 나의 과거에 비추어 볼 때 나는 많이 변했어요.
examples.romaji: Na-ui gwageoe bichueo bol ttae, naneun mani byeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Compared to my past, I have changed a lot.

examples.kr: 서울에 비추어 볼 때 부산은 훨씬 조용하다.
examples.romaji: Seoure bichueo bol ttae, busaneun hwolssin joyonghada.
examples.en: Compared to Seoul, Busan is much quieter.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들에 비추어 볼 때 그는 특히 뛰어납니다.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeure bichueo bol ttae, geuneun teughi ttwieonamnida.
examples.en: Compared to other people, he is particularly outstanding.

title: ~이다 보니 [ida boni] (Since, as)
short_explanation: Used to state a reason or cause that leads to a certain result, similar to 'since' or 'as' in English.
long_explanation: '~이다 보니 [ida boni]' expresses a cause-and-effect relationship. It is used when a state or habitual action gradually leads to a particular consequence, implying that the result became apparent over time.

examples.kr: 매일 같은 길을 걸어다니니 보니 이 동네에 대해 잘 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil gateun gileul georeodanini boni i dongne-e daehae jal alge doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since I walk the same route every day, I have come to know this neighborhood well.

examples.kr: 한국에서 한 달 살다 보니 한국어가 조금 더 편해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Hangug-eseo han dal salda boni hanguk-eoga jogeum deo pyeonhaejyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since living in Korea for a month, Korean has become a bit easier for me.

examples.kr: 우리는 같은 회사에서 일하다 보니 친해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun gateun hoesa-eseo ilhada boni chinhaejyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since we worked together at the same company, we became close.

examples.kr: 매일 아침에 운동을 하다 보니 몸이 건강해진 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim-e undong-eul hada boni mom-i geonganghaejin geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: Since I exercise every morning, it seems my body has become healthier.

title: ~이라면 그것은 [iramyeon geugeoseun] (If it’s called)
short_explanation: Used when describing or explaining something in detail if it is defined in a certain way.
long_explanation: '~이라면 그것은 [iramyeon geugeoseun]' is used to introduce a definition or explanation. It is roughly equivalent to saying 'if it's called...' in English and is followed by a more detailed description of the subject.

examples.kr: 사랑이라면 그것은 상대방을 배려하고 이해해 주는 것을 말한다.
examples.romaji: Sarangiramyeon geugeoseun sangdaebangeul baeryeohago ihaehaejuneun geoseul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called love, it means showing care and understanding toward the other person.

examples.kr: 자유라면 그것은 자신의 생각과 말을 제한받지 않는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jayuramyeon geugeoseun jasinui saenggakwa malul jehanbadji antneun geosida.
examples.en: If it's called freedom, it means not having your thoughts and words restricted.

examples.kr: 친구라면 그것은 서로를 이해하고 도와주는 사이를 말한다.
examples.romaji: Chinguramyeon geugeoseun seororeul ihaehago dowajuneun saireul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called a friend, it refers to a relationship where you understand and help each other.

examples.kr: 성공이라면 그것은 목표를 달성하고 자신의 꿈을 이룬 것을 말한다.
examples.romaji: Seonggongiramyeon geugeoseun mokpyoreul dalhagong jasinui kkumeul irun geoseul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called success, it means achieving your goals and fulfilling your dreams.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since then, after)
short_explanation: Used to express that something has been the case since a certain past event.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' denotes 'since then' or 'after' an event, emphasizing the lasting impact or continued change from that moment onward.

examples.kr: 그 사고 이래로 제가 차를 타지 못하게 되었어요, 그래서 버스와 지하철로 이동하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sago iraero jega cha-reul taji mothage doe-eotseoyo, geuraeseo beoseuwa jihacheollo idongeul hage doe-eotseoyo.
examples.en: Since that accident, I have not been able to drive a car, so I have had to travel by bus and subway.

examples.kr: 봄이래 제가 꽃 알레르기로 고생을 많이 했어요, 그래서 약을 계속 먹고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Bom irae jega kkoche allerugiro gosaeng-eul mani haesseoyo, geuraeseo yag-eul gyesog meogeoyo.
examples.en: Since spring, I have suffered a lot from flower allergies, so I am constantly taking medicine.

examples.kr: 지난 회의 이래로 사무실 분위기가 계속 나빠지고 있어요, 많은 사람들이 불만을 표시하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan hoeui iraero samusil bunwigiga gyesok nappajigo iss-eoyo, manheun saramdeuri bulmane pyosi hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since the last meeting, the office atmosphere has been continuously deteriorating, and many people are expressing their dissatisfaction.

examples.kr: 오랜만에 만난 친구가 결혼했다는 소식을 듣고 이래로는 못 마주쳤어요, 그래서 연락을 해야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oraenman-e mannahn chinguga gyeolhonhaessdaneun sosigeul deudgo iraero-neun mot majuchyeosseoyo, geuraeseo yeollageul haeya hal geos gatayo.
examples.en: Since I heard that my long-lost friend got married, I haven’t run into her, so I think I should contact her.

title: ~이야말로 [iyamallo] (Truly, really)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize that something or someone is the true or real example of a quality.
long_explanation: '~이야말로 [iyamallo]' is used to assert that the attached noun is the very or best example of a given quality. It can be translated as 'truly' or 'really' in English and is used for emphasis when stating a fact or situation.

examples.kr: 그 학생이야말로 모범적인 학생이에요, 그는 항상 열심히 공부하고 책임감이 강해요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksengiyamallo mobeomjeokin haksengieyo, geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhago chaegimgami ganghaeyo.
examples.en: That student is truly an exemplary student; he always studies hard and is very responsible.

examples.kr: 지금 이 순간이야말로 우리가 기다렸던 기회입니다, 이번 기회를 놓치면 더 이상의 기회는 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum i sunganiyamallo uriga gidaryeotdeon gihoeyibnida, ibeon gihoereul nohchimyeon deo isangui gihoeuneun eobseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: This moment is truly the opportunity we have been waiting for; if we miss it, there will be no more chances.

examples.kr: 이 보컬이야말로 이 밴드의 핵심입니다, 그녀의 목소리 없이는 이 밴드가 상상조차 되지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I bokoriyamallo i baendeu-ui haeksingibnida, geunyeoui moksori eobsineun i baendeuga sangsangjocha doeji anhayo.
examples.en: This vocalist is truly the core of the band; without her voice, the band is unimaginable.

examples.kr: 그 일이야말로 제 인생의 중요한 전환점이었습니다, 그 일로 인해 제 인생이 완전히 바뀌었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu iriyamallo je insaengui jungyohan jeonhwanjeomieossseubnida, geu ilro inhae je insaeng-i wanjeonhi bakkwieosseo.
examples.en: That incident was truly an important turning point in my life; my life changed completely because of it.

title: ~인 까닭에 [in kkadake] (Because, the reason why)
short_explanation: Indicates 'because' or 'the reason why' by giving the cause for the main clause.
long_explanation: '~인 까닭에 [in kkadake]' is a conjunction expression used in Korean to explain the reason or cause of an action, event, or situation. It is similar in meaning to 'because' or 'the reason why' in English and is generally used in formal or literary contexts (in contrast to colloquial forms like '때문에' or '해서').

examples.kr: 부모님이 건강하신 까닭에 저는 항상 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-i geonganghasin kkadake, jeoneun hangsang haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: I am always happy because my parents are healthy.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋은 까닭에 저는 오늘 산책하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jo-eun kkadake, jeoneun oneul sancaekhaleo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went for a walk today because the weather was nice.

examples.kr: 여행 준비를 철저히 한 까닭에 저는 여행 중에 불편함을 느끼지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng junbireul cheoljeohi han kkadake, jeoneun yeohaeng jung-e bulpyeonham-eul neukkiji anhass-eoyo.
examples.en: I didn’t feel uncomfortable during the trip because I thoroughly prepared for it.

examples.kr: 문제를 꼼꼼히 살펴본 까닭에 방학 중에 공부할 때 하나도 다루지 않는 문제는 없어요.
examples.romaji: Munje-reul kkomkkomhi salpyeobon kkadake, banghak jung-e gongbuhal ttae hanado daruji anneun munjeneun eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because I carefully examined the problem, there isn’t a single issue I avoid while studying during vacation.

title: ~인 즉 [in jeuk] (In other words)
short_explanation: Used to restate or clarify something; 'in other words', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~인 즉 [in jeuk]' is a phrase used in Korean to restate or clarify a previous statement in different words. It is similar to the English expressions 'in other words', 'that is to say', or 'namely' and offers additional clarification or perspective.

examples.kr: 그는 특이한 사람입니다, 즉 그가 평범한 사람과는 다르게 행동하는 것을 의미합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun teukiin saramimnida, injeok geuga pyeongbeonhan saramgwaneun dareuge haengdonghaneun geoseul uimihabnida.
examples.en: He is an unusual person; in other words, he behaves differently from ordinary people.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려웠습니다. 즉, 많은 학생들이 낮은 점수를 받았다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeowosseumnida. Injeok, maneun haksaengdeuri najeun jeomsureul badatneun geosimnida.
examples.en: This exam was difficult; that is to say, many students received low scores.

examples.kr: 당신은 제 최고의 친구입니다, 즉 제가 가장 신뢰하는 사람입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun je choegoui chinguimnida, injeok jegaga gajang sinroehaneun saramimnida.
examples.en: You are my best friend; in other words, you are the person I trust the most.

examples.kr: 지구가 따뜻해지고 있습니다, 즉 지구 온난화 현상이 일어나고 있는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jiguga ttatteutaejigo issseumnida, injeok jigu onnanhwa hyeonsangi ileonago issneun geosimnida.
examples.en: The Earth is getting warmer; in other words, global warming is happening.

title: ~처럼 하다 [cheoreom hada] (To act as if, pretend to)
short_explanation: Expresses that someone behaves as if they are in a certain state; 'pretend to' or 'act as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼 하다 [cheoreom hada]' is used to describe when someone imitates or mimics a particular state or behavior. In everyday Korean, speakers often use the expression with the auxiliary ‘척 하다’ to mean 'pretend to.'

examples.kr: 그는 사람들에게 행복한 척 하며 웃었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun saramdeurege haengboghan cheok hameo useosseoyo.
examples.en: He pretended to be happy and laughed to make people feel good.

examples.kr: 제가 이해한 척 행동하려고 노력했지만, 사실 많은 것을 이해하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega ihaehan cheok haengdongharyeogo noryeokhaessjiman, sasil manheun geoseul ihaehaji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to act as if I understood, but in fact, I didn’t understand many things.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신의 문제를 모른 척 행동했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasineui munjeleul moreun cheok haengdonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She acted as if she didn’t know about her own problem.

examples.kr: 그는 상황을 제어할 수 있는 척 행동하려고 했지만, 사실은 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sanghwangeul jeeohal su itneun cheok haengdongharyeogo haessjiman, sasileun geureohji anhayo.
examples.en: He tried to act as if he could control the situation, but in reality, he couldn’t.

title: ~커지다 [keojida] (Become bigger, more important)
short_explanation: Expresses that something grows in size, significance, or importance.
long_explanation: The verb '커지다 [keojida]' indicates that something becomes bigger, more significant, or more important. It can be used for physical size as well as abstract or emotional growth, making it versatile in various contexts.

examples.kr: 나는 자라면서 내 꿈이 더 커지고 중요해져서 내 삶이 바뀌었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jarimyeonseo nae kkumi deo keojigo jungyohajaeseo nae salmi bakkwieosseo.
examples.en: As I grew up, my dreams became bigger and more important, and my life changed.

examples.kr: 그 회사는 확장하면서 그의 역할이 점점 중요하게 커졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geu hwesa-neun hwakjanghamyeonseo geuui yeoghal-i jeomjeom jungyohage keojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: As the company expanded, his role became increasingly important.

examples.kr: 저희 집 가족의 사랑은 저희가 함께 시간을 보내며 점점 커져요.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jib gajog-ui sarangeun, jeohui-ga hamkke siganeul bonaemyeo jeomjeom keojyeoyo.
examples.en: Our family's love grows bigger as we spend time together.

examples.kr: 이슈가 계속되면서 그 문제의 중요성은 커져만 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Isugagi gyesokdoemyeonseo geu munjeui jungyoseong-eun keojyeoman gasseoyo.
examples.en: As the issue continued, the importance of that problem only grew.

title: ~키로 하다 [kiro hada] (Intend to, plan to)
short_explanation: Denotes the speaker's intention or resolution to do something.
long_explanation: The form '~키로 하다 [kiro hada]' is used in Korean to express a decision, plan, or intention for a future action. It conveys a sense of resolution and deliberate commitment, and is generally translated as 'intend to' or 'plan to' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 완벽하게 배울 키로 했습니다 그래서 매일 많은 연습을 하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul wanbyeokhage baeul kiro haetsseumnida, geuraeseo maeil maneun yeonseubeul hago issseumnida.
examples.en: I have decided to learn Korean perfectly, so I am practicing a lot every day.

examples.kr: 우리는 내년에 결혼할 키로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun naenyeone gyeolhonhal kiro haetsseumnida.
examples.en: We have decided to get married next year.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 시작할 키로 했어요 그래서 매일 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Daieteureul sijakhal kiro haetsseumnida, geuraeseo maeil undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I have decided to start dieting, so I am exercising every day.

examples.kr: 사장님은 회사를 확장할 키로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Sajangnimeun hoesareul hwakjanghal kiro haetsseumnida.
examples.en: The boss has decided to expand the company.

title: ~하기에는 [hagineun] (Considering)
short_explanation: Used to express 'considering' or 'given that'.
long_explanation: '~하기에는 [hagineun]' is used when taking into account a certain condition or fact before making a judgment or decision. It is attached to a verb stem (as in '하기에는') to indicate that, given that condition, the following statement holds true.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 와서 축구를 하기에는 좀 어렵겠어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun biga wasseo chukgureul hagineun jom eoryeobgesseoyo.
examples.en: Considering that it's raining today, it might be a bit difficult to play soccer.

examples.kr: 저는 돈이 너무 없어서 여행을 가기에는 불가능해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun doni neomu eopsseo yeohaengeul gagineun bulganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: Considering that I don't have much money, it's impossible for me to travel.

examples.kr: 이 프로젝트를 완성하기에는 시간이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: I peurojekteureul wanseonghagineun sigani bujokhaeyo.
examples.en: Considering the time, it's not enough to complete this project.

examples.kr: 이 영화를 보기에는 너무 무서워서 안될 거 같아요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaleul bogineun neomu museowoseo andoel geo gatayo.
examples.en: Considering it's too scary, I don't think I can watch this movie.

title: ~하기는 하다 [hagineun hada] (Do it somehow)
short_explanation: Conveys that someone does something, though not very well or adequately.
long_explanation: The expression '~하기는 하다 [hagineun hada]' is used to imply that while an action is indeed performed, it may not be done proficiently or to the expected standard.

examples.kr: 제가 요리를 하기는 하는데, 그렇게 맛있게는 안 나와요.
examples.romaji: Jega yorireul hagineun haneunde, geureoke masitge-neun an nawayo.
examples.en: I do cook, but it doesn't turn out that delicious.

examples.kr: 우리 회사에는 일을 하기는 하는데, 잘 하는 사람이 별로 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hwesaeneun ireul hagineun haneunde, jal haneun sarami byeollo eopseoyo.
examples.en: In our company, people do work, but there aren’t many who do it well.

examples.kr: 그는 학교를 다니기는 하는데, 실제로는 못 하는 과목이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakgyoreul danigineun haneunde, siljero-neun mot haneun gwamogi manh-ayo.
examples.en: He does attend school, but in reality, there are many subjects he struggles with.

examples.kr: 나는 영어를 말하기는 하는데, 자연스럽게 말하진 못해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yeong-eoreul malhagineun haneunde, jayeon-seureopge malhajin moth-ayo.
examples.en: I do speak English, but I can't speak it fluently.

title: ~하기야 [hagiya] (Indeed, truly)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize or affirm a statement; 'indeed', 'truly', 'to be sure'.
long_explanation: '~하기야 [hagiya]' is a form used to strongly affirm the truth of a statement or to emphasize one’s viewpoint. It is akin to saying 'indeed' or 'truly' in English.

examples.kr: 요즘 친구들이 공부하기야 쉽지 않아요, 그러니까 매일 night study가 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum chingudeuri gongbuhagiya swipji anayo, geureonikka maeil night studyga piryohaeyo.
examples.en: Indeed, studying isn’t easy for my friends these days, so night study is necessary every day.

examples.kr: 이제 코로나19 바이러스가 퍼져서 여행하기야 어려워요, 그래서 집에서만 시간을 보내고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ije korona19 baireoseuga peojyeoseo yeohaenghagiya eoryeowoyo, geuraeseo jibeseoman siganeul bonaego isseoyo.
examples.en: Indeed, traveling is difficult now that Covid‑19 is spreading, so I’m spending time only at home.

examples.kr: 학교에 관한 것이 아니라면, 그것을 하다 하기야 꼭 원합니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe gwanhan geosi aniramyeon, geugeoseul hada hagiya kkok wonhamnida.
examples.en: Indeed, if it isn’t about school, I definitely want to do it.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만드는 것은 어렵다고 하기야 그렇습니다, 그러나 매일 노력하면 점차 능력이 향상될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Masinneun eumsigeul mandeuneun geoseun eoryeodago hagiya geuraeyo, geureona maeil noryeokhamyeon jeomcha neungryeogi hyangsangdoel geosibnida.
examples.en: Indeed, making delicious food is difficult, but if you try every day, your ability will gradually improve.

title: ~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Expresses 'as soon as' or 'whenever' an action occurs, another immediately follows.
long_explanation: '~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon]' is used to indicate that as soon as a certain action (expressed by the verb stem + 하다) happens, another action follows immediately or consequently.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침 일어나기만 하면 운동을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim ileonagiman hamyeon undongeul habnida.
examples.en: I exercise as soon as I wake up every morning.

examples.kr: 그녀가 집에 도착하기만 하면 바로 저녁을 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga jibe dochakhagiman hamyeon baro jeonyeogeul mandeureoyo.
examples.en: As soon as she arrives home, she starts to make dinner.

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나기만 하면 학생들이 즉시 학교를 떠납니다.
examples.romaji: Sueobi ggeutnagiman hamyeon haksaengdeuli jeugshi hakgyoreul tteonabnida.
examples.en: The students leave school immediately as soon as the class ends.

examples.kr: 그가 긴장하기만 하면 어깨가 떨립니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga ginjanghagiman hamyeon eokkaega tteollibnida.
examples.en: His shoulders shake whenever he gets nervous.

title: ~하면서도 [hamyeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express a contradictory situation or event occurring at the same time; 'while', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~하면서도 [hamyeonseodo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate two actions or states happening simultaneously, with an aspect of contradiction or conflicting elements. It's like saying 'although' or 'even when' in English, and it implies that despite the first action, the second one still occurs. It can be used to show an inconsistency between what is expected and what really happens.

examples.kr: 그녀는 회사에서 바쁘게 일하면서도 항상 일찍 집에 가서 아이들과 식사를 함께해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hoesaeseo bappeuge ilhamyeonseodo hangsang iljjik jibe gaseo aideulgwa siksa-reul hamkkehaeyo.
examples.en: Even as she works hard at the company, she always goes home early to have meals with her children.

examples.kr: 저는 공부에 집중하면서도 친구들과 소통하는 데에는 어려움이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbue jipjunghamyeonseodo chingudeulgwa sotonghaneun deeneun eoryeoumi isseoyo.
examples.en: While focusing on my studies, I find it difficult to communicate with my friends.

examples.kr: 그는 연인과 행복하게 지내면서도, 그녀가 항상 곁에 없을 때를 두려워해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeoningwa haengbokhage jinaemyeonseodo, geunyeoga hangsang gyeote eopseul ttaereul duryeowohaeyo.
examples.en: Even as he spends happy moments with his lover, he fears the times when she is not by his side.

examples.kr: 어머니는 항상 건강에 신경을 쓰면서도, 자신의 건강은 항상 무시하곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun hangsang geongange singyeongeul sseumyeonseodo, jasinui geongangeun hangsang musihagon haeyo.
examples.en: While mom always takes care of others’ health, she tends to ignore her own health.

title: ~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok] (The more... the more)
short_explanation: Used to express a correlation between two actions or situations; 'the more... the more'.
long_explanation: The '~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok]' grammar point is used to express a correlation between two things. The first clause shows what is increasing or decreasing, while the second clause shows the result. This pattern emphasizes that as one event or situation increases or decreases, a related event or situation also increases or decreases—much like the English expression 'the more... the more'.

examples.kr: 이것을 연습하면 연습할수록 더 잘해져서, 계속 연습하면 제가 마스터할 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseul yeonseubhamyeon yeonseubhalsurok deo jalhaejeoseo, gyesok yeonseubhamyeon jega maseuteo hal su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: The more I practice this, the better I get; so if I keep practicing, I could master it.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워지면 추워질수록 더 많은 사람들이 옷가게에 들렀어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojimyeon chuwojilsurok deo manheun saramdeuri otgage deulleosseoyo.
examples.en: The colder the weather gets, the more people stop by the clothing store.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 공부하면 공부할수록 그 언어에 대해 더 알고 싶어져요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeoreul gongbuhamyeon gongbuhalsurok geu eoneoe daehae deo algo sipheojyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more I want to know about the language.

examples.kr: 이 도시에 살면 살수록 더 많은 볼거리와 할 것들이 있는 걸 알게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: I dosiye salsumyeon salsurok deo manheun bolgeoriwa hal geosdeuli issneun geol alge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: The longer I live in this city, the more I find there is to see and do.

title: ~하자마자 [hajamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as soon as' or 'right after' something has happened.
long_explanation: '~하자마자 [hajamaja]' is a conjugation used in Korean to indicate an action that is immediately followed by another action with no gap in between. Essentially, it means 'as soon as' or 'right after.'

examples.kr: 학교에 도착하자마자 그는 수업에 바로 들어갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe dochakhajamaja geuneun sueobe baro deuleogassseubnida.
examples.en: As soon as he arrived at school, he went straight to class.

examples.kr: 저는 공항에 도착하자마자 택시를 불렀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gonghang-e dochakhajamaja taeksileul bulleosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived at the airport, I called a taxi.

examples.kr: 그녀는 일어나자마자 커피를 만들었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ileonajamaja keopireul mandeuleosseubnida.
examples.en: As soon as she woke up, she made coffee.

examples.kr: 회사에서 퇴근하자마자 집에 바로 가서 쉬었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo toeguenhajamaja jibe baro gaseo swieosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I got off work, I went straight home and rested.

title: ~해서 그런지 [haeseo geureonji] (Perhaps because)
short_explanation: Used to express a supposition, assumption, or speculation; 'perhaps because', 'maybe due to'.
long_explanation: '~해서 그런지 [haeseo geureonji]' is commonly used in Korean to indicate a speculative cause-and-effect relationship or supposition. It is generally translated as 'perhaps because' or 'maybe due to' and is used when the speaker is not completely certain about the cause but speculates based on observable evidence.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 좋아서 그런지 사람들이 많이 활동하는 것을 볼 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneureun nalssiga johaseo geureonji saramdeuri mani hwaldonghaneun geoseul bol su isseosseubnida.
examples.en: Perhaps because the weather is nice today, I could see a lot of people being active.

examples.kr: 그녀는 어제 다치고 나서 그런지 오늘은 엄청 조심스럽게 걸어갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun eoje dachigo naseo geureonji oneureun eomcheong josimseureopge georeogassseubnida.
examples.en: Maybe because she got hurt yesterday, she walked very carefully today.

examples.kr: 어제 짜장면을 너무 많이 먹었나 봐요. 오늘은 배가 아파서 그런지 컨디션이 좋지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jjajangmyeoneul neomu mani meogeossnabwayo. Oneureun baegi apaseo geureonji keondisyeoni joji anhayo.
examples.en: Perhaps because I ate too much black bean noodles yesterday, I don't feel well today.

examples.kr: 나는 꿈에서 그녀를 만났어서 그런지 오늘은 그녀가 계속 생각나요.
examples.romaji: Naneun kkumeseo geunyeoreul mannasseo geureonji oneureun geunyeoga gyesok saenggaknayo.
examples.en: Maybe because I met her in my dream, I keep thinking about her today.

title: ~하여서는 안 되다 [hayeoseoneun an dweda] (Must not)
short_explanation: Used to express prohibition or strong advice against doing something, which can be translated as 'must not' or 'should not'.
long_explanation: '~하여서는 안 되다 [hayeoseoneun an dweda]' is a grammar form used to indicate that something should not or must not occur. It is often used when giving strong advice or setting prohibitions, highlighting the negative consequences of the action.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여 + 하여서는 안 되다

examples.kr: 학생들이라고 해서 수업에 늦게 오는 것은 절대로 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeulirago haeseo sueobe neuje oneun geoseun jeoldaero hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: Just because they are students, they absolutely must not come to class late.

examples.kr: 의사로서 환자에 대한 사항을 외부에 누설하는 것을 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Uisaroseo hwanjae daehan sahangeul oebue nuseolhaneun geoseul hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: As a doctor, you must not leak patient information to the outside.

examples.kr: 내일 시험 때문에 밤을 새운다고 해서는 안 돼요. 건강이 먼저예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheom ttaemune bameul saeundago haeseoneun an dwaeyo. Geongangi meonjeoyeyo.
examples.en: You must not stay up all night because of tomorrow's exam. Health comes first.

examples.kr: 다른 사람에게 피해를 주는 행동을 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramege pihaereul juneun haengdong-eul hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: You must not engage in actions that harm others.

title: ~한테는 [hanteneun] (To, for someone)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the target or recipient of an action, similar to 'to' or 'for' in English.
long_explanation: '~한테는 [hanteneun]' is a construction in Korean used when the speaker wants to specify the recipient or target of an action. It is similar to 'to' or 'for' in English and is often used to single out someone in contrast to others.

examples.kr: 제 언니한테는 선물을 사려고 왔어요. 제 친구한테는 이메일로 메시지를 보낼 예정입니다.
examples.romaji: Je eonni-hanteneun seonmureul saryeogo wasseoyo. Je chingu-hanteneun imeiro mesijireul bonael yejeongimnida.
examples.en: I came here to shop for a gift for my older sister. I plan to send a message to my friend by email.

examples.kr: 아버지한테는 이 사실을 아직 알리지 않았어요. 언니에게만 이야기했어요.
examples.romaji: Abeoji-hanteneun i sasileul ajik alliji anasseoyo. Eonni-egeman iyagihasseoyo.
examples.en: I have not yet told my father about this; I only told my older sister.

examples.kr: 아이들한테는 단순한 언어로 설명해야 해요. 너무 복잡하면 이해할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Aideul-hanteneun dansunhan eoneoro seolmyeonghaeya haeyo. Neomu bokjabhamyeon ihaehal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: You need to explain in simple language to children; if it’s too complex, they won’t understand.

examples.kr: 그는 엄마한테는 항상 친절하지만, 아빠한테는 무례해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eomma-hanteneun hangsang chinjeolhajiman, abba-hanteneun muryehaeyo.
examples.en: He is always kind to his mom, but he is rude to his dad.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Used to express the worthiness of doing something.
long_explanation: '~할 만하다 [hal manhada]' is used to indicate that something is worth the effort, time, or cost invested in it. It can be translated as 'worth doing' or 'worth it' in English, expressing a subjective assessment of value.

examples.kr: 요리 공부를 계속하는 게 어렵지만, 맛있는 음식을 자주 먹을 수 있게 되니까 할 만해요.
examples.romaji: Yori gongbureul gyesokhaneun ge eoryeopjiman, masitneun eumsigeul jaju meogeul su itge doenikka hal manhaeyo.
examples.en: Continuing to study cooking is difficult, but it’s worth it because I get to eat delicious food often.

examples.kr: 이 작품은 비싸기는 하지만, 아름다운 디자인과 고품질로 볼 때 사는 것이 할 만해요.
examples.romaji: I jakpumeun bissagineun hajiman, areumdaun dijain-gwa gopumjillo bol ttae saneun geosi hal manhaeyo.
examples.en: This item is expensive, but considering its beautiful design and high quality, it’s worth buying.

examples.kr: 긴 시간을 기다리는 것은 힘들지만, 그 결과가 좋으면 할 만합니다.
examples.romaji: Gin siganeul gidarineun geoseun himdeuljiman, geu gyeolgwaga joheumyeon hal manhamnida.
examples.en: Waiting for a long time is tough, but if the result is good, it’s worth it.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 별로 재미있지 않기 때문에 보는 것이 할 만하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun byeollo jaemiitji anhgi ttaemune boneun geosi hal manhaji anhayo.
examples.en: This movie isn’t very interesting, so it’s not worth watching.

title: ~할 수밖에 없다 [hal subakke eopda] (Have no choice but to)
short_explanation: Used to express that there is no other option but to do what is mentioned.
long_explanation: '~할 수밖에 없다 [hal subakke eopda]' is used when there is no alternative but to perform the action mentioned. It implies that circumstances force one to act in a certain way.

examples.kr: 비가 오니까 우산을 가지고 갈 수밖에 없어요.
examples.romaji: Biga onikka usaneul gajigo gal subakke eopseoyo.
examples.en: Since it’s raining, I have no choice but to bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 시험이 있기 때문에 공부를 계속할 수밖에 없어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi itgi ttaemune gongbureul gyesokhal subakke eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because there is an exam, I have no choice but to keep studying.

examples.kr: 그녀가 그렇게 말했으니까, 나는 그녀를 신뢰할 수밖에 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga geureoke malhaessnika, naneun geunyeoreul sinroehal subakke eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: Since she said so, I had no choice but to trust her.

examples.kr: 지금 돈이 없어서 이렇게 저렴한 물건밖에 살 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum doni eopseoseo ireoke jeoryeomhan mulgeonbakke sal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I don’t have money now, so I have no choice but to buy such cheap items.

title: ~해 갈수록 [hae galsurok] (Increasingly, as time goes on)
short_explanation: Used to describe a situation where a condition progressively intensifies or becomes more serious.
long_explanation: The '~해 갈수록 [hae galsurok]' expression indicates that as time passes, a particular state or condition gradually becomes more intense or worsens. It can be used with both verbs and adjectives, similar to saying 'increasingly' or 'the more... the more' in English.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워질수록 감기에 걸리는 사람이 많아지는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojilsurok gamgie geollineun sarami manhajineun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The colder the weather gets, the more people seem to catch a cold.

examples.kr: 그녀는 알수록 더 매력적인 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun alsurok deo maeryeokjeogin saram-ieyo.
examples.en: The more I get to know her, the more attractive she becomes.

examples.kr: 책을 읽을수록 나의 사고력이 향상되는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Chaegeul ilgeulsurok naui sagoryeogi hyangsangdoeneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The more I read, the more I feel my thinking ability improves.

examples.kr: 저는 집에 있을수록 외로워져서, 밖에 나가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jibe isseulsurok werowojyeoseo, bakk-e nagago sipeoyo.
examples.en: The longer I stay at home, the lonelier I become; so I feel like going out.

title: ~해 보아야 [hae boaya] (Should try and see)
short_explanation: Used to suggest that somebody should try something out in order to know or understand it.
long_explanation: '~해 보아야 [hae boaya]' is used when suggesting that one should try something to truly understand or experience it. In English, it is similar to saying 'you should try and see.'

examples.kr: 음식이 신선한지 아는 방법은 먹어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigi sinseonhanji aneun bangbeobeun meogeoboaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know if the food is fresh is to try eating it.

examples.kr: 이 옷이 어떤지 아는 방법은 입어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I ot-i eotteonji aneun bangbeobeun ibeoboaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know how these clothes fit is to try them on.

examples.kr: 이 책이 재미있는지 아는 방법은 읽어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I chaegi jaemiitji aneun bangbeobeun ilgeo boaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know if this book is interesting is to try reading it.

examples.kr: 이 스포츠가 얼마나 재미있는지 아는 방법은 직접 해 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I seupocheuga eolmana jaemiinneunji aneun bangbeobeun jikjeop haeboaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know how fun this sport is is by trying it out yourself.

title: ~해오다 [haeoda] (Continue doing something until now)
short_explanation: Used to express an ongoing action from the past up to the present moment.
long_explanation: '해오다 [haeoda]' is used to denote an action that started in the past and continues until now. It literally means 'have been doing' and is often used to express a continuous habit, an ongoing action, or a series of actions over an extended period.

examples.kr: 나는 어렸을 때부터 피아노를 쳐오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoryeot taebuteo pianoreul chyeo-ogo isseoyo.
examples.en: I have been playing the piano since I was young.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 사업을 시작한 지 5년 동안 일해오고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu saeobeul sijakhan ji 5nyeon dongan ilhaeoogo issseumnida.
examples.en: We have been working on that business for five years since we started.

examples.kr: 세계 여행을 꿈꾸며 돈을 아껴오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Segye yeohaengeul kkumkkumyeo doneul akkyeo-ogo isseoyo.
examples.en: I have been saving money while dreaming of a world tour.

examples.kr: 우리는 친구가 왔을 때부터 함께 이야기해오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun chinguga wasseul ttaebuteo hamkke iyagihae-ogo isseoyo.
examples.en: We have been telling stories together since our friend arrived.

title: ~했건만 [haetgeonman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: The '~했건만 [haetgeonman]' form is used to express a contrasting situation or contradiction. It can be translated as 'but', 'nevertheless', or 'however' and is used when the speaker wants to present a fact or circumstance that conflicts with what was previously stated.

examples.kr: 저는 많이 노력했건만, 시험에 떨어졌습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun mani noryeokhaetgeonman, siheome ddeoleojyeossseubnida.
examples.en: I put in a lot of effort, but I failed the exam.

examples.kr: 친구는 어제 왔건만, 오늘은 못 왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguneun eoje watgeonman, oneureun mot watseubnida.
examples.en: My friend came yesterday, but he couldn’t make it today.

examples.kr: 음식은 맛있었건만, 가격이 너무 비쌌습니다.
examples.romaji: Eumsikeun masisseotgeonman, gagyeogi neomu bissassseubnida.
examples.en: The food was delicious, but it was too expensive.

examples.kr: 그녀는 예쁘다고 했건만, 저는 그렇게 생각하지 않았습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeppeudago haetgeonman, jeoneun geureohge saenggakaji anhaetseubnida.
examples.en: She said she was pretty, but I didn't think so.

title: ~했기 때문에 [haetgi ttaemune] (Because)
short_explanation: Used to express reason or cause, equivalent to 'Because' in English.
long_explanation: '~했기 때문에 [haetgi ttaemune]' is used to give a reason or cause. It refers retrospectively to an action or situation in the past that explains a present condition or outcome.
formation: Action Verb in Past Tense + 했기 때문에

examples.kr: 어제 늦게 잤기 때문에 오늘 아침에 일어나기 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje neutge jatgi ttaemune oneul achime ileonagi himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I went to bed late last night, it was hard for me to wake up this morning.

examples.kr: 미세먼지 농도가 높아서 창문을 열지 않았기 때문에 방이 더워졌어요.
examples.romaji: Mise meonjiga nongdoga nopaseo changmuneul yeolji anhatgi ttaemune bangi deowojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because the fine dust concentration was high, I didn't open the window and the room got hot.

examples.kr: 많은 공부를 했기 때문에 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Manneun gongbureul haetgi ttaemune siheomeseo joheun jeomsureul badasseoyo.
examples.en: Because I studied a lot, I got a good score on the exam.

examples.kr: 비가 왔기 때문에 운동화가 젖었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga watgi ttaemune undonghwaga jeojeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because it rained, my sneakers got wet.

title: ~했기에 [haetgie] (Because)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the reason or cause; 'because' or 'since'.
long_explanation: `~했기에 [haetgie]` is a conjunction that connects two sentences by showing that the first is the cause or reason for the second. It emphasizes that one situation exists because of another, equivalent to 'because' or 'since' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학문을 아주 좋아했기에, 대학에서 교수가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakmuneul aju joahaetgie, daehageseo gyosuga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She became a professor at the university because she really loved academics.

examples.kr: 저는 갈비를 많이 먹었기에, 지금 배가 너무 불러요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun galbireul manhi meogeotgie, jigeum baega neomu bulleoyo.
examples.en: I ate a lot of ribs, so now I am very full.

examples.kr: 오늘 일찍 일어났기에, 출근할 시간에 늦지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul iljjik ileonatgie, chulgeunhal sigane neujji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up early today, so I was not late for work.

examples.kr: 그는 개인적인 문제 때문에 스트레스를 받았기에, 단체 활동에 참여하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gaeinjeogin munje ttaemune seuteureseureul badatgie, danche hwaldonge chamyeohaji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He did not participate in the group activity because he was stressed due to personal issues.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (And then)
short_explanation: Used to express the progression of actions or events, indicating a consequential relationship.
long_explanation: The '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' expression is used in Korean to show that after an action or event, an unexpected or revealing result followed. It can be translated as 'and then' or 'so' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화했더니 그녀는 바빠서 전화를 받을 수 없다고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwahaetdeoni geunyeoneun bappaseo jeonhwareul badeul su eopsdago haesseoyo.
examples.en: I called her and then she said she was too busy to answer the call.

examples.kr: 저는 버스에서 내렸더니 지갑을 잃어버렸다는 것을 깨달았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun beoseueseo naeryeotdeoni jigabeul ilheobeoryeotdaneun geoseul kkaedalatseoyo.
examples.en: I got off the bus and then realized that I had lost my wallet.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽었더니 창문 밖에 비가 오고 있는 것을 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaeg-eul ilgeotdeoni changmun bakke biga ogo issneun geoseul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then I saw that it was raining outside the window.

examples.kr: 약을 먹었더니 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Yageul meogeotdeoni gibuni johajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I took a pill and then I felt better.

title: ~했어야 했다 [haesseoya haetda] (Had to)
short_explanation: Indicates that something 'had to' be done in the past, often expressing regret or missed opportunities.
long_explanation: '~했어야 했다 [haesseoya haetda]' is used to express that something should have been done or occurred in the past, even if it wasn’t. It often carries a sense of regret or a feeling that an opportunity was missed.

examples.kr: 어제 그 일을 끝냈어야 했는데, 시간이 부족해서 끝내지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje geu ileul kkeutnesseoya haetneunde, sigani bujokhaeseo kkeutnaeji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have finished that work yesterday, but I couldn’t because I didn’t have enough time.

examples.kr: 학원에 가서 공부했어야 했는데, 게임을 하느라고 갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Hagwone gaseo gongbuhaesseoya haetneunde, geimeul haneurago gal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I should have gone to the academy and studied, but I couldn’t because I was playing games.

examples.kr: 커피 대신 물을 마셨어야 했는데, 카페인이 많아서 잠이 안 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Keopi daesin mureul masyeosseoya haetneunde, kapeini manhaseo jami an wasseoyo.
examples.en: I should have drunk water instead of coffee, but I couldn’t sleep because there was too much caffeine.

examples.kr: 전화를 받았어야 했는데, 전화기를 못 봐서 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwaleul badesseoya haetneunde, jeonhwagireul mot bwaseo badji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have answered the phone, but I didn’t because I couldn’t see it.

title: ~혹은 [hogeun] (Or)
short_explanation: Used to express options or alternatives; 'or'.
long_explanation: '~혹은 [hogeun]' is a conjunction used to present two or more alternatives or choices without prioritizing one over another, similar to 'or' in English.

examples.kr: 당신은 커피 혹은 차를 원하세요?
examples.romaji: Dangsin-eun keopi hogeun chaleul wonhaseyo?
examples.en: Would you like coffee or tea?

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하기 위해서는 시간 혹은 노력이 필요하겠어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhagi wihaeseoneun sigan hogeun noryeogi pilyohagesseoyo.
examples.en: Time or effort is needed to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 그는 강아지 혹은 고양이를 키우고 싶어 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gangaji hogeun goyangireul kiugo sip-eo haesseoyo.
examples.en: He wanted to raise a puppy or a kitten.

examples.kr: 여름 휴가를 보내기 위해 바닷가 혹은 산에서 휴가를 보낼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoleum hyugaleul bonaegi wihae badasga hogeun san-eseo hyugaleul bonael su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: You can spend your summer vacation at the beach or in the mountains.

title: 후에야 [hueya] (Only after)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something happened or was realized only after a certain event or time.
long_explanation: '후에야 [hueya]' is a compound word formed from '후에' (after) and '야' (only). It emphasizes that an action or realization occurs only after a specified event or period has passed – the precondition for what follows.

examples.kr: 그녀가 날 떠나고 후에야 난 그녀를 얼마나 사랑하는지 알았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nal tteonago hueya nan geunyeoreul eolmana saranghaneunji alatseoyo.
examples.en: Only after she left me did I realize how much I loved her.

examples.kr: 시험을 보고 후에야 이 문제의 정답이 무엇인지 기억이 났어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul bogo hueya i munjeui jeongdabi mueosinji gieogi nasseoyo.
examples.en: Only after taking the test did I remember what the correct answer was.

examples.kr: 나는 대학을 졸업한 후에야 진짜로 배워야 할 것이 무엇인지 이해했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daehageul joreophan hueya jinjjaro baewoya hal geosi mueosinji ihaehaetseoyo.
examples.en: Only after I graduated from university did I understand what I really needed to learn.

examples.kr: 일을 시작한 후에야 할 일이 얼마나 많은지 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Ileul sijakhan hueya hal ili eolmana manheunji alge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Only after starting work did I realize how much there was to do.

title: ~흔히 [heunhi] (Commonly, often)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an event or situation happens frequently or is commonly known.
long_explanation: '~흔히 [heunhi]' is an adverb used in Korean to demonstrate that something happens frequently, is a common occurrence, or is typically known. It is very similar to English expressions like 'often', 'commonly', 'usually' or 'typically'. It is used in both objective descriptions of facts and in subjective observations.

examples.kr: 흔히 사람들은 건강한 음식은 맛이 없다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Heunhi saramdeureun geonganghan eumsigeun masi eopdago saenggakhabnida.
examples.en: People often think that healthy food is tasteless.

examples.kr: 한국에서는 혼자 살아가는 사람들을 흔히 '싱글'이라고 부릅니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoseoneun honja saraganeun saramdeureul heunhi 'single'irago bureubnida.
examples.en: In Korea, people living alone are commonly referred to as 'singles'.

examples.kr: 우리는 흔히 우리나라 음식보다 외국 음식을 더 많이 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun heunhi urinara eumsikboda oeguk eumsigeul deo manhi meokseumnida.
examples.en: We often eat more foreign food than our country's food.

examples.kr: 봄이 오면 흔히 피는 꽃인 벚꽃은 많은 사람들에게 잘 알려져 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Bomi omyeon heunhi pineun kkotin beotkkotseun manheun saramdeurege jal allyeojyeo issseubnida.
examples.en: Cherry blossoms, one of the flowers that commonly bloom in spring, are well known to many people.

title: ~되다 [doeda] (To become)
short_explanation: Used to express a change into a different state or condition; 'to become'.
long_explanation: '~되다 [doeda]' is used to indicate that someone or something has changed into a new state or condition. It expresses a transformation or transition from one state to another.

examples.kr: 날씨가 덥다가 갑자기 춥게 되었어요. 그래서 모두 감기에 걸렸어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga deopdaga gapjagi chupge doeeosseoyo. Geuraeseo modu gamgie geollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather suddenly became cold after being hot, so everyone caught a cold.

examples.kr: 그녀는 열심히 공부해서 세계에서 가장 젊은 교수가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeolsimhi gongbuhaseo segyeeseo gajang jeolmeun gyosuga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She studied hard to become the youngest professor in the world.

examples.kr: 나의 친구는 한국어를 배워서 번역가가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Na-ui chinguneun hangugeoreul baewoseo beonyeokgaga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend studied Korean and became a translator.

examples.kr: 자그마했던 새끼 고양이가 큰 고양이가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jageumahaessdeon saekki goyangiga keun goyangiga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The tiny kitten became a big cat.

title: ~잖다 [janda] (You know, isn't it)
short_explanation: Used to state information the speaker assumes the listener already knows.
long_explanation: '~잖다 [janda]' is a sentence-ending phrase used to indicate the speaker's assumption that the listener is already aware of the information being shared. It's akin to saying 'you know' or 'isn’t it' in English. This grammar point can be used to confirm facts or imply shared knowledge.

examples.kr: 너 오늘 학교 가야 하잖아, 왜 아직도 놀고 있어?
examples.romaji: Neo oneul hakgyo gaya hajanha, wae ajikdo nolgo isseo?
examples.en: You have to go to school today, you know, so why are you still playing?

examples.kr: 우리 내일 시험이 있잖아. 그래서 오늘 공부하려고.
examples.romaji: Uri naeil siheomi issjanha. Geuraeseo oneul gongbuharyeogo.
examples.en: We have a test tomorrow, you know. So, I plan to study today.

examples.kr: 너 그 사람을 알잖아, 그런데 요즘 어떻게 지내?
examples.romaji: Neo geu saram-eul al janha, geureonde yojeum eotteoke jinae?
examples.en: You know that person, don't you? So, how's he doing these days?

examples.kr: 지금 시간이 늦었잖아, 우린 이제 공부해야 해.
examples.romaji: Jigeum sigani neu-eossjanha, urin ije gongbuhayeya hae.
examples.en: It's late now, you know, so we should study.

title: ~져/지다 [jyeo/jida] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to depict changes in state, emotion, condition, or situation, similar to 'become' or 'get' in English.
long_explanation: '~져/지다 [jyeo/jida]' is a conjugation that indicates transformation or change. It can mean 'become' or 'get' and is used to describe shifts in state, feelings, or conditions.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 더워져서 밖에 나가기가 힘들어졌어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu deowojyeoseo bakke nagagiga himdeureojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather has become so hot that it's hard to go outside.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에서 인기가 많아져서 많은 사람들이 그녀를 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoeseo ingiga manhajyeoseo manheun saramdeuli geunyeoreul alge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She has become popular in school, so many people got to know her.

examples.kr: 그는 그림을 많이 그리니까, 그림 그리는 실력이 정말 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geurimeul manhi geurinikka, geurim geurineun sillyeogi jeongmal joahjyeosseoyo.
examples.en: He has become really good at drawing because he draws a lot.

examples.kr: 일하는데 집중하니까 시간이 너무 빨리 가버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Ilhaneunde jipjunghanikka, sigani neomu ppalli gabeollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Time has gone by so fast because I was focused on work.

title: ~졌다가 [jyeotdaga] (Was once, but)
short_explanation: Used to express that something was once in a certain state or condition, but then changed again.
long_explanation: '~졌다가 [jyeotdaga]' is used to indicate a sequence where the subject was once in one state and then changed to another—often reverting or fluctuating. It is typically attached to verbs in the past tense.

examples.kr: 나는 문을 열졌다가 다시 닫았어요. 그런데 친구가 오길 기다릴 수 없어서요.
examples.romaji: Naneun muneul yeoljyeotdaga dasi dadasseoyo. Geureonde chinguga ogil gidaril su eopseoseoyo.
examples.en: I opened the door, but then closed it again. However, I couldn't wait for my friend to come.

examples.kr: 그 레스토랑은 며칠 전에 문을 연졌다가 오늘 바로 닫았어요.
examples.romaji: Geu reseutorangeun myeochil jeone muneul yeonjyeotdaga oneul baro dadasseoyo.
examples.en: That restaurant had opened just a few days ago, but it closed again today.

examples.kr: 아이들은 컴퓨터 게임을 하다가 숙제를 그만두어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Aideuleun keompyuteo geimeul hadaga sukjereul geumandueoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: The kids had to stop playing computer games and do their homework.

examples.kr: 나의 친구는 직장을 받았다가 한 달 후에 해고되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Naui chinguneun jikjangeul badatdaga han dal hue haegodoeeotseumnida.
examples.en: My friend got a job, but then got fired after a month.

title: ~즉 [jeuk] (That is to say, namely)
short_explanation: Used to restate or clarify a point with more detail; 'namely', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~즉 [jeuk]' is a conjunction used in Korean to re-explain or add further details to a statement. It is equivalent to 'namely' or 'that is to say' in English and helps clarify or specify information.

examples.kr: 이 연구의 결과를 바탕으로 즉, 우리가 본 바로는 지구 온난화는 인간의 활동 때문임이 분명하다.
examples.romaji: I yeonguui gyeolgwareul batangeuro jeuk, uriga bon baroneun jigu onnanhwaneun inganui hwaldong ttaemunimi bunmyeonghada.
examples.en: Based on the results of this research, that is to say, from what we have seen, it is clear that global warming is due to human activities.

examples.kr: 그는 국제관계 전문가이다. 즉, 그는 세계의 다양한 나라들 간의 문제를 연구한다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gukje gwangye jeonmungaida. Jeuk, geuneun segyeui dayanghan naradeul gan-ui munjeleul yeonguhanda.
examples.en: He is an expert in international relations. That is to say, he studies issues between various countries around the world.

examples.kr: 이 메일은 너에게만 보낼 것이다. 즉, 너는 이 메시지의 유일한 수신자다.
examples.romaji: I meireun neoegeman bonael geosida. Jeuk, neoneun i mesijui yuilhan susinjada.
examples.en: I will send this email to you only. Namely, you are the only recipient of this message.

examples.kr: 그는 내 좋은 친구이다. 즉, 나는 그를 아주 잘 알고 있다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun nae joheun chinguida. Jeuk, naneun geureul aju jal algo itda.
examples.en: He is a good friend of mine. That is to say, I know him very well.

title: ~지 않을까 싶다 [ji anheulkka sipda] (I think perhaps)
short_explanation: Expresses an assumption or supposition that something might be; it suggests that the speaker thinks something is likely.
long_explanation: The structure '~지 않을까 싶다' is used to express a guess or speculation about a situation. It conveys uncertainty as well as a hopeful anticipation about what might happen or be true.

examples.kr: 그가 이번 시험에 잘 볼 수 있을지 않을까 싶어요, 왜냐하면 그는 항상 열심히 공부하고 있거든요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ibeon siheome jal bol su isseulji anheulkka sipeoyo, waenyahamyeon geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhago issgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I think perhaps he might do well on this test, because he is always studying hard.

examples.kr: 날씨가 나빠지지 않을까 싶어요, 구름이 많아지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga nappajiji anheulkka sipeoyo, gureumi manhajigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I think the weather might get worse; the clouds are increasing.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 집에 도착할 수 있을지 않을까 싶어요, 비행기가 시간에 맞춰 출발했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame jibe dochakhal su isseulji anheulkka sipeoyo, bihaengiga sigane matchwo chulbalhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I think perhaps I could reach home tonight since the airplane has departed on time.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화 보러 갈 수 있을지 않을까 싶은데, 어떻게 생각하세요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e yeonghwa boreo gal su isseulji anheulkka sipeunde, eotteohge saenggakhaseyo?
examples.en: I think perhaps we might go see a movie this weekend; what do you think?
