title: ~지 않을까 하다 [ji anheulkka hada] (I guess, I suspect)
short_explanation: Used to express one's conjecture or prediction; 'I think', 'I guess', 'I suspect'.
long_explanation: '~지 않을까 하다' is used to express a guess or suspicion about a situation when the speaker is not completely sure. It conveys the speaker's uncertainty and expectation about what might be true.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지 않을까 해서 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga olji anheulkka haeseo usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: I brought an umbrella because I thought it might rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀가 좋아하는 사람을 만나지 않을까 해서 신경 쓰고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga joahaneun sarameul mannaji anheulkka haeseo singyeong sseugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm nervous because I suspect she might meet the person she likes.

examples.kr: 지금 새벽이니까 아마 모든 사람들이 잠들지 않을까 해요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum saebyeoginikka ama modeun saramdeuri jamdeulji anheulkka haeyo.
examples.en: Since it's dawn now, I guess everyone might be asleep.

examples.kr: 내 친구가 이번 시험에 합격하지 않을까 해서 축하 메시지를 준비하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguga ibeon siheome hapgyeokhaji anheulkka haeseo chukha mesijireul junbihago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm preparing a congratulatory message because I think my friend might pass this exam.

title: ~지 않을래 [ji anheullae] (I don't want to)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's intention not to do something.
long_explanation: '~지 않을래' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate that the speaker does not want to perform a certain action. It shows a strong personal decision and is typically used in informal contexts.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 운동하러 가지 않을래요, 몸이 좀 피곤해서 쉬고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul undonghareo gaji anheullaeyo, momi jom pigonhaeseo swigo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I don't want to go exercise today because I feel a bit tired and want to rest.

examples.kr: 저는 너무 많이 먹었기 때문에 디저트는 먹지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neomu mani meogeoss-gi ttaemune dijeoteuneun meokji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: I don't want to eat dessert because I ate too much.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 말고, 그 사람은 제가 대신 말하지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Neomu geogjeonghaji malgo, geu saram-eun jega doae daesin malhaji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: Don't worry too much; I don't want to speak on your behalf to that person.

examples.kr: 이 옷이 마음에 들지 않아서 사지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: I os-i ma-eum-e deulji anhasseo saji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: I don't like this outfit, so I don't want to buy it.

title: ~지요 [jyo] (~지, right?)
short_explanation: A casual way to seek agreement or confirmation from the listener, similar to 'right?' or 'isn't it?' in English.
long_explanation: ~지요 [jyo] is a commonly used ending in conversational Korean that seeks agreement or confirmation. It softens statements and is often used in friendly dialogues. In English, it can be roughly translated as 'right?' or 'isn't it?'.

examples.kr: 날씨가 매우 좋지요?
examples.romaji: Nalssiga maeu johjiyo?
examples.en: The weather is very nice, isn't it?

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 학교에 가야 하지요?
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil hakgyoe gaya hajiyo?
examples.en: We have to go to school tomorrow, right?

examples.kr: 이 영화가 재미있었지요?
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaga jaemiisseotjiyo?
examples.en: This movie was interesting, wasn't it?

examples.kr: 그녀는 아직도 학생인 것 같지요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ajikdo haksaengin geot gatjiyo?
examples.en: She's still a student, right?

title: ~진행하다 [jinhaenghada] (To proceed)
short_explanation: Used to express the progression or continuation of an action or event.
long_explanation: '~진행하다 [jinhaenghada]' indicates that an action or event is being carried out or continued. It is equivalent to 'to proceed with' or 'to continue' in English and can be used in contexts such as work, study, or any ongoing process.

examples.kr: 연구팀은 이 이슈에 대해 조사를 진행하고 있습니다. 그들은 다양한 데이터를 수집하면서 정보를 분석하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongutimeun i isue daehae josareul jinhaenghago itsseumnida. Geudeureun dayanghan dateoreul sujibhamyeo jeongboreul bunseokhago itsseoyo.
examples.en: The research team is conducting an investigation on this issue; they are analyzing information as they collect various data.

examples.kr: 오늘 회의를 얼마나 빨리 진행하느냐에 따라서 제 시간에 퇴근할 수 있을지 결정됩니다.
examples.romaji: Oneul hoeuireul eolmana ppalli jinhaenghaneunyae ddalaseo je sigane tuikeunhal su iss-eulji gyeoljeongdoebnida.
examples.en: Whether I can leave work on time today is decided by how quickly the meeting proceeds.

examples.kr: 학생들은 공부를 계속 진행하다 보니 시간이 어떻게 지나갔는지도 모르겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun gongbureul gyesok jinhaenghada boni sigani eotteoke jinagatneunjido moreugesseumnida.
examples.en: The students were so engrossed in their studies that they didn’t realize how fast time passed.

examples.kr: 프로젝트 계획 중, 우리 팀은 문제 해결을 위한 논의를 진행하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Peurojekteu gyehoeg jung, uri timeun munje haegyeoreul wihan noniureul jinhaenghago itsseumnida.
examples.en: During the project planning, our team is proceeding with discussions to resolve the issue.

title: ~차라리 [charari] (Rather, instead)
short_explanation: Used to express a preference for one option over another; 'rather', 'instead'.
long_explanation: '~차라리 [charari]' is used to indicate that one option is preferable to another, often implying that the chosen option is the lesser of two evils or simply more favorable. It is typically used in the pattern: '[A] 보다는 차라리 [B]'.

examples.kr: 나는 그냥 집에서 혼자 있기보다는 차라리 밖에서 친구들과 놀러 나갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyang jibeseo honja itgibodaneun charari bakeseo chingudeulgwa nolreo nagasseoyo.
examples.en: I would rather go out and play with friends than just stay home alone.

examples.kr: 당신이 직접 거짓말하기보다는 차라리 솔직하게 말하면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jigjeob geojitmalhagi bodaneun charari soljikhage malhamyeon johgesseoyo.
examples.en: I'd rather you speak honestly than tell a lie yourself.

examples.kr: 그 물건을 사지 않기보다는 차라리 돈을 저금하는 것이 낫습니다.
examples.romaji: Geu mulgeoneul saji anhgibodaneun charari doneul jeogeumhaneun geosi natseupnida.
examples.en: It’s better to save money than to buy that item.

examples.kr: 그럴 거면 차라리 아무 말도 하지 않는 것이 나아요.
examples.romaji: Geureol geomyeon charari amu maldo haji anneun geosi naayeo.
examples.en: If that’s the case, I’d rather you said nothing at all.

title: ~처럼만 [cheoreomman] (Just like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or comparison; 'just like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼만 [cheoreomman]' is used to compare one thing to another, emphasizing an exclusive similarity. It can be translated as 'just like' or 'as if' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다른 사람들과 달리, 마치 꿈을 꾸는 것처럼만 행동했어.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun dareun saramdeulgwa dalli, machi kkumeul kkuneun geotcheoreomman haengdonghaesseo.
examples.en: Unlike others, she acted as if she were dreaming.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 마치 엄마가 만든 것처럼만 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsikeun machi eommaga mandeun geotcheoreomman masisseoyo.
examples.en: This food tastes just like the one my mother makes.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 봄처럼만 따뜻해요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga bomcheoreomman ttatteushaeyo.
examples.en: The weather today is warm just like spring.

examples.kr: 그는 마치 나를 알아보는 것처럼만 쳐다보았어.
examples.romaji: Geuneun machi nareul araboneun geotcheoreomman chyeodaboasseo.
examples.en: He looked at me as if he recognized me.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (To make)
short_explanation: Used to express causing someone or something to be in a certain state.
long_explanation: '~게 하다 [ge hada]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate that someone causes or makes another person or thing perform an action or be in a certain state. The verb or adjective before it is used in its descriptive stem form. It is equivalent to 'make' or 'let' in English.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저를 일찍 자게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeoreul iljjik jage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: My mother made me go to bed early.

examples.kr: 선생님은 우리를 많이 공부하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun urireul mani gongbu hage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: The teacher made us study a lot.

examples.kr: 재수없는 사고로 그는 그녀를 울게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jaesueopsneun sago-ro geuneun geunyeoreul ulge haesseoyo.
examples.en: Due to an unfortunate accident, he made her cry.

examples.kr: 그녀는 남편을 행복하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nampyeoneul haengbokhage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: She made her husband happy.

title: ~타다 [tada] (To take, ride)
short_explanation: Denotes the action of riding or taking a vehicle.
long_explanation: '~타다 [tada]' is used with means of transportation to indicate that the subject is riding or taking that vehicle to a destination. It applies to buses, taxis, subways, cars, etc.

examples.kr: 나는 출근할 때 항상 버스를 타고 회사에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun chulgeunhal ttae hangsang beoseureul tago hoesae gamnida.
examples.en: When I go to work, I always take a bus to the office.

examples.kr: 피곤해서 오늘은 택시를 타고 집에 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Pigontaeseo oneureun taeksireul tago jibe doraowassseoyo.
examples.en: Because I was tired, I took a taxi and returned home today.

examples.kr: 여동생은 지하철을 타고 학교에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Yeodongsaengeun jihacheoreul tago hakgyoe gamnida.
examples.en: My younger sister takes the subway to school.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 자가용 차를 타고 출근합니다.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun jagayong chareul tago chulgeunhamnida.
examples.en: My father goes to work by taking his own car.

title: ~하게 하다 [hage hada] (Make someone do)
short_explanation: Used when one causes or allows someone else to perform an action.
long_explanation: The '~하게 하다 [hage hada]' structure indicates that one person is causing or permitting another to do something. The action verb is conjugated with ~하게, and then 하다 is added to complete the construction. The subject causes the action, while the object is the person who performs it.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저를 일찍 자게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeoreul iljjik jage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: My mother made me go to bed early.

examples.kr: 선생님은 우리를 많이 공부하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun urireul mani gongbu hage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: The teacher made us study a lot.

examples.kr: 재수없는 사고로 그는 그녀를 울게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jaesueopsneun sago-ro geuneun geunyeoreul ulge haesseoyo.
examples.en: Due to an unfortunate accident, he made her cry.

examples.kr: 그녀는 남편을 행복하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nampyeoneul haengbokhage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: She made her husband happy.

title: ~하여야만 [hayeoyaman] (Only by doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that an objective can be achieved only by doing a certain action.
long_explanation: '~하여야만 [hayeoyaman]' conveys the meaning 'only by doing...' It is used to emphasize that a specific goal or result can be attained only if a certain action is performed.

examples.kr: 성공하려면 열심히 공부하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 실패할 가능성이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seonggongharyeomyeon yeolsimhi gongbuhayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon silpaehal ganeungseongi isseoyo.
examples.en: To succeed, you must study hard; otherwise, there is a chance of failure.

examples.kr: 병이 고쳐지려면 약을 복용하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 건강을 회복할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Byeongi gochyeojiryeomyeon yageul bogyonghayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon geongangeul hoebokhal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: To recover from an illness, you must take medicine; otherwise, you cannot regain your health.

examples.kr: 이루고 싶은 꿈이 있으면 계속 노력하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 그 꿈은 단지 꿈일 뿐이에요.
examples.romaji: Irugo shipeun kkumi issneumyeon gyesok noryeokhayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon geu kkumeun danji kkumil ppunieyo.
examples.en: If you have a dream you want to achieve, you must keep trying; otherwise, that dream is just a dream.

examples.kr: 목표를 달성하려면 계획을 세우고 그 계획을 따라야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 목표를 이룰 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Mokpyoreul dalseongharyeomyeon gyehoegeul sewoogo geu gyehoegeul ttarayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon mokpyoreul irul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: To achieve your goal, you must make a plan and follow it; otherwise, you won't be able to reach your goal.

title: ~해서는 안 되다 [haeseoneun an dwae] (Must not, shouldn't)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express prohibition or things that shouldn't be done.
long_explanation: '~해서는 안 되다' is a common ending in Korean that translates to 'must not' or 'shouldn't'. It indicates actions or behaviors that are prohibited, and it is used to express restrictions, warnings, or advice. It can be attached to both action and descriptive verbs.

examples.kr: 너는 남의 물건을 가져서는 안 된다. 그것은 도둑질이다.
examples.romaji: Neoneun namui mulgeoneul gajyeoseoneun an doenda. Geugeoseun dodukjilida.
examples.en: You must not take other people's belongings. That's stealing.

examples.kr: 아이들은 먼저 놀아서는 안 된다. 먼저 숙제를 하고, 그 후에 놀아야 한다.
examples.romaji: Aideureun meonjeo noraseoneun an doenda. Meonjeo sukjereul hago, geu hue noraya handa.
examples.en: Children should not play first; they must do their homework first, then play.

examples.kr: 당신은 늦게 자서는 안 된다. 건강을 해칠 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-eun neutge jaseoneun an doenda. Geongangeul haechil su issseubnida.
examples.en: You should not stay up late. It can harm your health.

examples.kr: 우리는 문제를 무시해서는 안 된다. 대신, 우리는 그것을 해결해야 한다.
examples.romaji: Ulineun munjeleul musihaseoneun an doenda. Daesin, ulineun geugeoseul haegyeolhaeya handa.
examples.en: We must not ignore the problem. Instead, we have to solve it.

title: ~해서야 [haeseoya] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the necessity or requirement to achieve a purpose or goal; 'in order to', 'so that'.
long_explanation: '~해서야' is a verb ending in Korean that expresses that a certain action is required to achieve a specific goal. It is similar to 'in order to' or 'so that' in English, implying that the desired outcome depends on performing the action.

examples.kr: 학교에 더 잘 적응하기 위해서야, 일상적으로 학교 활동에 더 많이 참여해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyo-e deo jal jeogeungeul wihaeseoya, ilsangjeogeuro hakgyo hwaldonge deo manhi chamyeohaeya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to better adapt to school, you need to participate more in daily school activities.

examples.kr: 올리는 무게를 더 높이려면, 나는 더 열심히 운동해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ollineun mugeleul deo nopihalymyeon, naneun deo yeolsimhi undonghaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to lift more weight, I need to exercise harder.

examples.kr: 회사 직원들에게 좋은 이미지를 보여주기 위해서야, 더 많이 야근해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hoesa jigweondeul-ege joheun imijileul boyeojugi wihaeseoya, deo manhi yageunhaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to show a good image to the employees, I have to work late more.

examples.kr: 요리를 잘 배우기 위해서야, 재료에 대해 더 많이 이해하려면 노력해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yolileul jal baeugi wihaeseoya, jaeli-e daehae deo manhi ihaehalyeomyeon noryeokhaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to learn to cook well, you have to make an effort to understand more about the ingredients.

title: ~해야겠다 [haeyagetta] (Should, must, have to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a strong need or determination to perform an action; 'should', 'must', 'have to'.
long_explanation: '~해야겠다' is used in Korean to express a firm decision or determination to carry out an action. It conveys the sense that something must be done and is often used in self-directed statements or diary entries.

examples.kr: 밖이 너무 더워요, 다음부터는 자외선 차단제를 발라야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Baggi neomu deowoyo, daeumbuteoneun jayeonseon chadanjereul ballyagesseoyo.
examples.en: It's too hot outside; I should apply sunscreen next time.

examples.kr: 마지막 시험도 끝났으니, 이제 책을 치워야겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Majimak siheomdo ggeutnasseuni, ije chaeg-eul chiwoyagessseubnida.
examples.en: Since the last exam is over, I must put my books away now.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부했으니, 이제 잠을 자야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaeseuni, ije jameul jayagesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied hard, so I should sleep now.

examples.kr: 다음 주에 중요한 회의가 있어서, 제 시간 관리를 해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Daeum jue jungyohan hoeuiga isseoseo, je sigan gwonlireul haeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I have an important meeting next week, so I must manage my time.

title: ~해야지 [haeyaji] (I should)
short_explanation: Used to express a determination or resolution; 'I should'.
long_explanation: '~해야지' is used in casual, informal speech to express a self-suggestion or resolution regarding something you plan to do. It conveys the speaker's determination to carry out an action in the future.

examples.kr: 시험이 코 앞이니까, 이제 공부를 시작해야지.
examples.romaji: Siheomi ko apinikka, ije gongbureul sijakhaeyaji.
examples.en: Since the exam is right around the corner, I should start studying now.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 친구들과 영화를 보기로 했으니, 티켓을 사야지.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame chingudeulgwa yeongwareul bogiro haesseuni, tikeseul saya ji.
examples.en: I decided to watch a movie with my friends tonight, so I should buy tickets.

examples.kr: 헬스장에서 오래 동안 운동하지 않았으니, 내일 일찍 가야지.
examples.romaji: Helseujangeseo orae dongan undonghaji anhasseuni, naeil iljjik gaya ji.
examples.en: I haven’t exercised in a long time at the gym, so I should go early tomorrow.

examples.kr: 오늘 늦게 잠들었으니, 아침에 빵을 사 먹어야지.
examples.romaji: Oneul neutge jamdeureosseuni, achime bbangeul sa meogeoya ji.
examples.en: I went to bed late today, so I should buy bread for breakfast in the morning.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (After doing something, result)
short_explanation: Used to show that an action is followed by an unexpected outcome or change.
long_explanation: '~했더니' is used in Korean to indicate that after an action is performed, a particular (often surprising) result occurs. It expresses a cause-and-effect relationship where the outcome is notable.

examples.kr: 저는 오랜만에 친구를 만났더니 친구가 많이 변했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oraenmane chingureul mannatdeoni, chinguga manhi byeonhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I met my friend after a long time, and he had changed a lot.

examples.kr: 집에 왔더니 청소를 다 해놨어요.
examples.romaji: Jib-e watdeoni cheongsoleul da haenwasseoyo.
examples.en: When I got home, the house was already cleaned.

examples.kr: 실시간 업데이트 확인을 했더니 큰 변화가 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Silsigan eobdeiteu hwagin-eul haetdeoni keun byeonhwaga iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: After checking the real-time updates, there was a big change.

examples.kr: 전화를 끊었더니 실수로 잘못 연결된 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwaleul kkeunh-eossdeoni silsuro jalmot yeongyeoldoengeoyeyo.
examples.en: After I hung up the phone, it turned out that I had mistakenly connected.

title: ~했었는데 [haesseotneunde] (Had done but)
short_explanation: Used to indicate an action that was completed in the past but is still connected to the present or resulted in an unexpected contrast.
long_explanation: '~했었는데' is a verb ending that expresses an action completed in the past which, in context, leads to a contrast or an unexpected situation in the present.

examples.kr: 책을 샀었는데 도서관에서 같은 책을 발견했어요, 그래서 결국 두 권이 있는 상황이 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul sasseossneunde, doseogwan-eseo gateun chaeg-eul balgyeonhaesseoyo, geuraeseo gyeolguk du gwon-i issneun sanghwang-i dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had bought a book but then found the same book at the library, so I ended up having two copies.

examples.kr: 저녁을 먹었었는데 친구가 갑자기 나를 불러서 또 저녁을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeogeul meogeosseotneunde, chinguga gabjagi nareul bulleoseo tto jeonyeogeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I had already eaten dinner but then my friend suddenly called me and I had dinner again.

examples.kr: 학교에 일찍 도착했었는데 갑자기 수업이 취소되었어요, 그래서 결국 집에 일찍 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyo-e iljjik dochakhaesseotneunde, gabjagi sueop-i chwisodoeeosseoyo, geuraeseo gyeolguk jib-e iljjik dol-agasseoyo.
examples.en: I had arrived at school early, but then the class was suddenly cancelled, so I ended up going home early.

examples.kr: 몇 시간동안 공부했었는데 시험 문제를 모두 틀려버렸어요, 공부한 내용과 다르게 나왔거든요.
examples.romaji: Myeot sigandongan gongbuhaesseotneunde, siheom munjeleul modu tullyeobeoryeosseoyo, gongbuhan naeyong-gwa dareuge nawassgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I had studied for several hours but then got all the test questions wrong—the questions were different from what I had studied.

title: ~했을 텐데 [haesseultende] (Would have done but)
short_explanation: Used to express that something 'would have' happened but for some reason did not.
long_explanation: '~했을 텐데' is used in Korean to describe an action or state that was expected to occur but did not due to certain circumstances. It expresses a contrast between expectation and reality.

examples.kr: 저는 원래 오늘 공항에 갔을 텐데, 비행기표가 매진되서 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun wonrae oneul gonghang-e gasseultende, bihanggipyo-ga maejindweseo mot gat-eoyo.
examples.en: I would have gone to the airport today, but I couldn't because the airplane tickets were sold out.

examples.kr: 그녀는 숙제를 다 했을 텐데, 갑자기 컴퓨터가 고장나서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sujereul da haesseultende, gabjagi keompyuteoga gojangnaseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: She would have done all her homework, but she couldn't because her computer suddenly broke down.

examples.kr: 우리는 지난 주말에 영화를 봤을 텐데, 그날 너무 바빠서 못 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jinan jumale yeonghwareul bwasseultende, geunal neomu bappaseo mot bwasseoyo.
examples.en: We would have watched a movie last weekend, but we couldn't because we were too busy that day.

examples.kr: 내가 너에게 전화했을 텐데, 핸드폰 배터리가 다 떨어져서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naega neoege jeonhwahasseultende, haendeupon baeteoriga da tteol-eojyeoseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I would have called you, but I couldn't because my phone battery died.

title: ~혹시 [hoksi] (By any chance)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or to make polite inquiries.
long_explanation: The expression '혹시' is used at the beginning of sentences to indicate a level of uncertainty or to politely propose a possibility. It softens questions or suggestions and is useful when inquiring about something hypothetically.

examples.kr: 혹시 나중에 틈나시면, 우리 같이 커피나 마시러 갈래요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi najunge teumnasimyeon, uri gachi keopina masireo gallaeyo?
examples.en: By any chance, if you have time later, would you like to go for a coffee with me?

examples.kr: 혹시 내일 비가 올까요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi naeil biga olkkayo?
examples.en: Do you think it will rain by any chance tomorrow?

examples.kr: 혹시 그분을 아세요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi geubuneul aseyo?
examples.en: Do you know that person by any chance?

examples.kr: 혹시 시간 좀 있으세요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi sigan jom isseuseyo?
examples.en: Do you have some time by any chance?

title: ~힘들다 [himdeulda] (It's hard to)
short_explanation: Used to express that something is difficult or hard to do.
long_explanation: '힘들다' is a common expression in Korean used to describe difficulty or hardship in performing an action. It can be translated as 'it's hard to' in English and often conveys a sense of struggle or challenge.

examples.kr: 일어나기 힘들었어요, 왜냐하면 어제 밤에 너무 늦게 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Ireonagi himdeureosseoyo, waenyahamyeon eoje bame neomu neutge jasseyo.
examples.en: It was hard to get up because I went to bed so late last night.

examples.kr: 영어를 배우기 힘들다고 생각했지만, 매일 공부하니까 점점 익숙해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongeoreul baeugi himdeuldago saenggakhaetjiman, maeil gongbuhannikkaji jeomjeom iksukhaejeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought learning English was hard, but as I studied every day, I gradually got used to it.

examples.kr: 건강을 유지하기 힘들지만, 운동을 꾸준히 하고, 잘 먹으면 가능해요.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul yujihagi himdeuljiman, undongeul ggujunhi hago, jal meogeumyeon ganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: Keeping healthy is hard, but it's possible if you exercise regularly and eat well.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 처음 배울 때, 글자를 외우기 힘들었어요. 하지만 계속 연습하다 보니 점점 쉬워졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul cheoeum baeul ttae, geuljareul oeuwgi himdeureosseoyo. Hajiman gyesok yeonseuphada boni jeomjeom swiwojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I first started learning Korean, memorizing the characters was hard. But as I kept practicing, it gradually got easier.

title: ~는 김에 [neun gimae] (Used to express that someone does something while doing another action)
short_explanation: Used to depict that someone performs a certain action while already engaged in another.
long_explanation: The ending '~는 김에' is used when one is already doing something and takes advantage of that situation to do something else. It conveys the idea of 'while you are at it' or 'since you are doing one thing, you might as well do another.'

examples.kr: 제가 책을 읽는 김에, 아들이 저를 부르는 소리를 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chaegeul ilkneun gimae, adeuri jeoreul bureuneun sorireul deureosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was reading a book, I heard my son calling me.

examples.kr: 먹는 김에 티비를 봐도 돼요?
examples.romaji: Meogneun gimae tibireul bwado dwaeyo?
examples.en: Can I watch TV while eating?

examples.kr: 그는 달리는 김에 손톱을 물어 뜯었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun dallineun gimae sontobeul mureo tteocheosseoyo.
examples.en: He bit his nails while running.

examples.kr: 저는 샤워하는 김에 노래를 불렀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun syawohaneun gimae noraereul bulleosseoyo.
examples.en: I sang a song while taking a shower.

title: ~기 시작하다 [sijakada] (To begin to, start to)
short_explanation: Used to express that something begins to occur or a state starts to develop.
long_explanation: The form '~기 시작하다' is used to indicate the initiation of an action or change in state. It marks the moment when something starts to happen.

examples.kr: 회사에서 문제가 생기기 시작해서 많은 사람들이 짜증이 나기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo munjega saenggigi sijakhaeseo maneun saramdeul-i jjajeungi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Problems began to occur at the company, and many people started to feel annoyed.

examples.kr: 진짜 봄이 시작했을 때, 꽃들이 피기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Jinjja bom-i sijakhaess-eul ttae, kkotdeul-i pigi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: When real spring began, the flowers started to bloom.

examples.kr: 나는 평소보다 많이 배가 고프기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pyeongsoboda manhi baega gopeugi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I started to feel hungrier than usual.

examples.kr: 우리는 오류가 발생하기 시작했다는 것을 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun oryuga balseenghagi sijakhaessdaneun geoseul alge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: We began to realize that errors were starting to occur.

title: ~남다 [namda] (To remain, be left over)
short_explanation: Used to express that something remains or is left over.
long_explanation: The term '~남다' is used to indicate that something remains – whether a physical quantity or an abstract element – after other parts have been used up or removed.

examples.kr: 저도 공부하고 싶었지만, 시험 준비를 위해 시간이 거의 남지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeodo gongbuhago sipeotjiman, siheom junbireul wihae sigani geoui namji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I also wanted to study, but I hardly had any time left to prepare for the exam.

examples.kr: 결혼식에 초대된 모든 사람들이 도착한 후에는 음식이 많이 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeolhonsig-e chodaedoen modeun saramdeul-i dochakhan hue, eumsigi mani namasseoyo.
examples.en: After everyone invited to the wedding arrived, there was a lot of food left over.

examples.kr: 우리는 호숫가를 다 걸은 후, 더 이상 볼거리가 남지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun hosutgareul da georeun hu, deo isang bolgeoriga namji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: After we walked along the lakeside, there was nothing more to see.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나간 후, 이별의 첫날 밤에 그리움만 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nagan hu, ibyeol-ui cheosnal bame geuriumman namasseoyo.
examples.en: After she left, on the first night of parting, only longing remained.

title: ~네요 [neyo] (Express surprise)
short_explanation: Used when the speaker discovers something new or unexpected.
long_explanation: The ending '~네요' is used to express surprise, realization, or a newly noticed fact. It can convey sentiments such as 'I see,' 'Oh,' or 'Wow,' indicating that the speaker has become aware of something.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 따뜻하네요, 아침에는 춥다고 생각했는데요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal ttatteuthneyo, achimeun chubdago saenggakhaetneundeyo.
examples.en: The weather is really warm today, although I thought it was cold this morning.

examples.kr: 그녀가 노래를 정말 잘 부르네요, 이전에 들어본 적이 없어서 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga noraereul jeongmal jal bureuneyo, ijeon-e deureobon jeogi eopseoseo moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: She sings really well; I haven’t heard her sing before.

examples.kr: 와, 이 케이크가 정말 맛있네요, 처음 먹어보는 맛이에요.
examples.romaji: Wa, i keikeuga jeongmal masitneyo, cheoeum meogeoboneun masieyo.
examples.en: Wow, this cake is really delicious—it’s a taste I’m experiencing for the first time.

examples.kr: 어, 비가 오네요, 우산을 가져왔어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eo, biga oneyo, usaneul gajyeowasseoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: Oh, it’s raining. I should have brought an umbrella.

title: ~다고 [dago] (Saying that)
short_explanation: Used to indirectly report what someone said, thought, or felt.
long_explanation: The ending '~다고' is used to quote or report someone’s speech, thoughts, or feelings indirectly. It functions similarly to saying 'saying that' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 내가 밥을 먹었다고 생각했어요, 하지만 저는 아직 밥을 먹지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naega babeul meogeossdago saenggakhaesseoyo, hajiman jeoneun ajik babeul meokji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He thought that I had eaten, but I haven’t eaten yet.

examples.kr: 친구가 오늘은 비가 온다고 말했어요, 그래서 나는 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga oneureun biga ondago malhaesseoyo, geuraeseo naneun usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend said that it would rain today, so I brought an umbrella.

examples.kr: 선생님이 시험이 어렵다고 말했어요, 그래서 부지런히 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi siheomi eoryeopdago malhaesseoyo, geuraeseo bujireonhi gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher said that the test would be difficult, so I studied diligently.

examples.kr: 엄마가 오늘 밤 늦게 들어오지 마라고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga oneul bam neutge deureooji marago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My mom said not to come home late tonight.

title: ~다는 [daneun] (The fact that)
short_explanation: Used to denote the fact or idea that something has been stated or quoted.
long_explanation: '~다는' is used to emphasize the content of a statement or the fact that something is said or known. It is often used when reporting or conveying information that was heard from another source.

examples.kr: 그는 자신의 실수를 인정한다는 사실이 얼마나 어려운지 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jasinui silsureul injeonghandaneun sasil-i eolmana eoryeounji moreumnida.
examples.en: He doesn’t know how hard it is to admit his mistakes.

examples.kr: 나는 내가 그녀를 사랑한다는 것을 처음으로 깨달았다.
examples.romaji: Naneun naega geunyeoreul saranghandaneun geoseul cheoeumeuro kkaedaraessda.
examples.en: I realized for the first time that I love her.

examples.kr: 퍼피 님의 회사가 본격적으로 확장한다는 소식을 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Peopi nimui hoesaga bongyeokjeogeuro hwakjanghandaneun sosigeul deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I heard that Puppy’s company is expanding in earnest.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에 네가 결혼한다는 사실을 들었어.
examples.romaji: Oneul achime neoga gyeolhonhandaneun sasil-eul deureosseo.
examples.en: This morning, I heard that you are getting married.

title: ~다면서요 [damyeonseyo] (Said that)
short_explanation: Used when quoting someone's words or conveying information heard from someone else.
long_explanation: The expression '~다면서요' is used to relay information that was reported or said by someone else. It combines the declarative form with a quoting marker to indicate that the speaker is passing along what was heard.

examples.kr: 영희가 서울에 살고 있다면서요, 정말 그런 건지 알 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghiga Seoure salgo itdamyeonseyo, jeongmal geureon geonji al suga eopseoyo.
examples.en: You said that Young Hee lives in Seoul, but I can’t really tell if that’s true.

examples.kr: 집에 일찍 돌아오라고 했다면서요, 그런데 왜 아직도 안 와요?
examples.romaji: Jibe iljjik doraorago haetdamyeonseyo, geureonde wae ajikdo an wayo?
examples.en: You said to come home early, but why haven’t you come yet?

examples.kr: 친구가 낼 학교에 안 온다고 했다면서요, 아마 아프지 않았나요?
examples.romaji: Chinguga nael hakgyoe an ondago haetdamyeonseyo, ama apeuji anhatnayo?
examples.en: My friend said he won’t come to school tomorrow; maybe he’s not feeling well?

examples.kr: 나중에 커피 한 잔 같이 할 것을 약속했다면서요, 그런데 왜 연락이 없나요?
examples.romaji: Najunge keopi hanjan gachi hal geoseul yaksokhaetdamyeonseyo, geureonde wae yeonragi eomnayo?
examples.en: You promised to have a cup of coffee later, but why haven’t you contacted me?

title: ~던데 [deonde] (Used to)
short_explanation: Used to express reminiscence or describe how something used to be.
long_explanation: The ending '~던데' is a past tense form used to recall how things were in the past. It is often used in a reminiscing context or to highlight a contrast between past and present.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 머리를 길게 기르던데, 언제부터 짧게 자르기 시작했어요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang meorireul gilge gireudeonde, eonjebuteo jjalbge jareugi sijakhaesseoyo?
examples.en: He used to always grow his hair long—when did he start cutting it short?

examples.kr: 내 친구는 예전에는 채소를 안 좋아했던데, 이제는 건강을 위해 열심히 먹는다고 하네요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguneun yejeoneneun chaesoreul an joahaetdeonde, ijeneun geongangeul wihae yeolsimhi meokneundago haneyo.
examples.en: My friend used to dislike vegetables, but now he says he eats them diligently for his health.

examples.kr: 나는 어릴 때 청소를 정말 싫어했던데, 이제는 좋아해서 매일 하는 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoril ttae cheongso-reul jeongmal sirheohaetdeonde, ijeneun joahaeseo maeil haneun pyeonieyo.
examples.en: I used to really hate cleaning when I was young, but now I like it and do it every day.

examples.kr: 우리는 어렸을 때부터 함께 공부하던데, 지금은 각자 다른 대학교에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Urineun eoryeosseuttobuteo hamkke gongbuhadeonde, jigeumeun gakja dareun daehakgyoe danyeoyo.
examples.en: We used to study together when we were young, but now we attend different universities.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (To try to, to make sure to)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention of making something happen or ensuring an action occurs.
long_explanation: The structure '~도록 하다' is used when someone takes measures or makes an effort to ensure that a certain action or state is achieved. It implies intention or control over making something happen.
formation: Verb stem + 기 / Noun + 도록 하다

examples.kr: 우리는 우리의 직원들이 충분한 휴식을 취하도록 해야 합니다. 그렇게 하지 않으면 그들의 효율성이 줄어들 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun uriui jikwon-deul-i chungbunhan hyusigeul chwihadorok haeya hamnida. Geureoke haji anheumyeon geudeurui hyoyulseongi jureodeul su issseubnida.
examples.en: We should ensure our employees get enough rest. If not, their efficiency might decrease.

examples.kr: 생일 파티를 계획하면서 모든 것이 완벽하게 되도록 해야 해요. 아무래도 그것은 아버지의 특별한 날이니까요.
examples.romaji: Saeng-il patireul gyehoekhamyeonseo modeun geosi wanbyeokhage doedorok haeya haeyo. Amuraedo geugeoseun abeojiui teugbyeolhan narinikkayo.
examples.en: While planning the birthday party, everything must be perfect—after all, it’s Dad’s special day.

examples.kr: 반장으로서, 나는 모든 학생들이 숙제를 완료하도록 해야 합니다. 그럼 선생님은 우리에게 불만을 가질 이유가 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Banjang-euroseo, naneun modeun haksaengdeul-i sukje-reul wanryohadorok haeya hamnida. Geureom seonsaengnimeun uriege bulmaneul gajil iyuga eobseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: As class president, I must ensure that all students complete their homework—then the teacher won’t have any reason to complain.

examples.kr: 고객이 우리의 제품에 만족하도록 최선을 다해야 합니다. 그렇게 하면 우리의 비즈니스가 성장할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaegi uriui jepum-e manjokhadorok choeseoneul dahaeya hamnida. Geureoke hamyeon uriui bijeuniseuga seongjanghal su isseul geosibnida.
examples.en: We must do our best to ensure that customers are satisfied with our product. By doing so, our business can grow.

title: ~든지 [deunji] (Whether or)
short_explanation: Used to express indecision between two or more options; 'whether or'.
long_explanation: The conjunction '~든지' is used to indicate that any of the given alternatives is acceptable or that the speaker is indifferent about the choice. It is often used to show that no matter which option is chosen, the outcome will be similar.

examples.kr: 당신이 들어오든지 나가든지 저는 상관하지 않아요, 중요한 것은 작업이 계속되어야 한다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini deureodeunji nagadeunji jeoneun sanggwanhaji anhayo, jungyohan geos-eun jageobi gyesogdoeya handaneun geosibnida.
examples.en: Whether you come in or go out, I don’t care; what’s important is that the work must continue.

examples.kr: 비가 오든지 맑은 날이든지 저는 항상 산책하러 나갑니다.
examples.romaji: Biga odeunji malgeun narideunji jeoneun hangsang sanchaekhareo nagamnida.
examples.en: Whether it’s raining or a clear day, I always go out for a walk.

examples.kr: 당신이 이해하든지 못하든지 저는 계속 설명하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini ihaehadeonji mothadeonji, jeoneun gyesok seolmyeonghagessseubnida.
examples.en: Whether you understand or not, I will keep explaining.

examples.kr: 강아지가 짖든지 안 짖든지, 마치 대화를 나누는 것처럼 인사하는 것이 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: Gang-ajiga jijdeunji an jijdeunji, machi daehwareul nanuneun geoscheoreom insahaneun geosi johseubnida.
examples.en: Whether the dog barks or not, it’s nice to greet it as if you were having a conversation.

title: ~라는 것이다 [raneun geosida] (It means that)
short_explanation: Used to indicate or define the meaning of a statement; 'it means that'.
long_explanation: '~라는 것이다' is a grammatical structure that turns a clause into a noun phrase to explain or define its implication. It is commonly used after a verb or descriptive verb to emphasize that something signifies a particular fact or idea.
formation: Verb + 라는 것이다 OR Descriptive Verb + 라는 것이다

examples.kr: 그녀가 사진을 찍는다는 것은, 그녀가 사진을 좋아한다는 뜻이다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga sajineul jjikneundaneun geoseun, geunyeoga sajineul joahandaneun tteusida.
examples.en: The fact that she takes photographs means she likes photography.

examples.kr: 그가 항상 일찍 일어난다는 것은, 그는 아침형 인간이라는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Geuga hangsang iljjik ireonandaneun geoseun, geuneun achimhyeong inganiraneun geosida.
examples.en: The fact that he always gets up early means that he is a morning person.

examples.kr: 가을이 오면 나무 잎이 노란색으로 변한다는 것은, 가을의 특성이라는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Ga-euli omyeon namu ip-i nolan saeg-eulo byeondandaneun geoseun, gaeul-ui teugseong-iraneun geosida.
examples.en: The fact that the leaves turn yellow when autumn comes means it is a characteristic of autumn.

examples.kr: 우리가 어떤 문제를 가지고 있다는 것은, 우리가 그 문제를 해결해야 한다는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Uriga eotteon munje-reul gajigo issdaneun geoseun, uriga geu munje-reul haegyeolhaeya handaneun geosida.
examples.en: The fact that we have a problem means we need to solve it.

title: ~라도 [rado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least' or 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~라도' is used to indicate a minimum or acceptable alternative. It can be attached to a noun or verb stem to mean 'at least' or 'even if' under a given condition, often softening a statement or presenting a fallback option.

examples.kr: 달까지 걸어가기는 어렵지만, 사진이라도 찍자.
examples.romaji: Dalkkaji georeogagineun eoryeopjiman, sajin-irado jjikja.
examples.en: Although it's hard to walk to the moon, let's at least take a picture.

examples.kr: 그는 일하기 힘들다고 했지만, 일이라도 시켜야 하는 게 아니에요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun ilhagi himdeuldago haejiman, il-irado sikyeoya haneun ge anieyo?
examples.en: He said working is hard, but don't we have to make him work at least?

examples.kr: 최소한 사과라도 했어야 하지 않았을까요? 그러면 상황이 좀 더 나아질 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Choesohan sagwarado haesseoya haji anhaesseulkka-yo? Geureomyeon sanghwang-i jom deo naajil su isseosseul tende.
examples.en: Shouldn't she have at least apologized? Then the situation could have been better.

examples.kr: 집에 가지 않을 거라면, 연락이라도 해주었어야 하는 게 아니겠어요?
examples.romaji: Jibe gaji anheul georamyeon, yeonragirado haejueosseoya haneun ge anigesseoyo?
examples.en: If you weren't going home, shouldn’t you have at least made a call?

title: ~러 [reo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the purpose or intention of an action; 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~러' is a grammar pattern attached to a verb stem to express the purpose or intent of an action. It is equivalent to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English and is commonly used when going somewhere or doing something with a specific goal in mind.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우러 한국에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeureo, hanguge wassseoyo.
examples.en: I came to Korea in order to learn Korean.

examples.kr: 그는 책을 사러 서점에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaegeul sareo, seojome gasseoyo.
examples.en: He went to the bookstore to buy a book.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저녁 식사를 준비하러 부엌에 가셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeonyeok siksa-reul junbihareo, bueoge gasyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Mother went to the kitchen to prepare dinner.

examples.kr: 친구들과 영화를 보러 영화관에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa yeonghwareul boreo, yeonghwagw-e gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the movie theater to watch a movie with friends.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or attempt to do something; 'try to'.
long_explanation: The construction '~려고 하다' is used to convey an intention, plan, or attempt to do something. It expresses a planned future action or an effort, without guaranteeing success.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 새로운 단어를 10개 배우려고 해요, 그래서 한국어 향상을 위해 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil saeroun daneoreul 10gae baeuryeogo haeyo, geuraeseo hangugeo hyangsangeul wihae noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I try to learn 10 new words every day, so I am making an effort to improve my Korean.

examples.kr: 아플 때에도 항상 웃으려고 해요, 그것이 저의 방식입니다.
examples.romaji: Apeul ttaeedo hangsang useuryeogo haeyo, geugeosi jeoui bangshigibnida.
examples.en: Even when I'm sick, I always try to smile; that's my way.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 일찍 자려고 하지만, 항상 실패하고 말아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang iljjik jaryeogo hajiman, hangsang silpaehago maraeyo.
examples.en: He always tries to go to bed early, but always ends up failing.

examples.kr: 우리는 연습하고 공부해서 공연을 성공적으로 마치려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeonseuphago gongbuhaeseo gongyeoneul seonggongjeogeuro machiryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: We tried to finish the performance successfully by practicing and studying.

title: ~려는 [ryeoneun] (Intending to)
short_explanation: Used to express a future intention, plan, or aim.
long_explanation: ~려는 is used to indicate that someone intends or plans to do something in the future. It carries the nuance of will or purpose, even if the outcome is not yet decided.

examples.kr: 내일 출장 가려는 사람은 저 혼자입니다. 다른 사람들은 모두 바쁩니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil chuljang garyeoneun sarameun jeo honjaimnida. Dareun saramdeureun modu bappumnida.
examples.en: I am the only one intending to go on a business trip tomorrow; everyone else is busy.

examples.kr: 건강한 식생활을 위해 채식주의자가 되려는 사람이 많습니다.
examples.romaji: Geonganghan siksaenghwaleul wihae chaesikjuuijaga doeryeoneun sarami manheumnida.
examples.en: There are many people intending to become vegetarians for a healthier diet.

examples.kr: 토익 시험을 준비하려는 학생들은 많은 시간을 공부에 투자하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Toik siheomeul junbiharyeoneun haksaengdeuleun manheun siganeul gongbue tujahago isseumnida.
examples.en: Students intending to prepare for the TOEIC exam are investing a lot of time in studying.

examples.kr: 제 주말 계획은 코딩을 배우려는 것입니다만, 평소보다 더 많은 시간과 노력이 필요합니다.
examples.romaji: Je jumal gyehoek-eun kodingeul baeuryeoneun geosimnida man, pyeongsoboda deo manheun sigangwa noryeogi pil-yohabnida.
examples.en: My weekend plan is to learn coding, but it requires more time and effort than usual.

title: ~로써 [rossyeo] (By means of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the role, means, or capacity in which something is done.
long_explanation: '~로써' is used after a noun to express the manner or capacity in which an action is performed – similar to saying 'by means of' or 'as' in English.

examples.kr: 제가 학생으로써 선생님께서 알려주신 것을 모두 이해했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jega haksaeng-eurosseo, seonsaengnimkkeseo allyeojusin geoseul modu ihaehaesseumnida.
examples.en: As a student, I understood everything the teacher explained.

examples.kr: 바이올리니스트로써 그녀는 세계적으로 인정받았습니다.
examples.romaji: Ba-iolliniseuteuro-sseo, geunyeoneun segyejeogeuro injeongbadassseumnida.
examples.en: As a violinist, she has gained worldwide recognition.

examples.kr: 나는 엔지니어로써 이 문제를 해결할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun enjinieo-ro-sseo, i munjeleul haegyeolhal su isseumnida.
examples.en: As an engineer, I can solve this problem.

examples.kr: 지도자로써 그는 팀을 잘 이끌고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jidojaro-sseo, geuneun timeul jal ikkeulgo isseumnida.
examples.en: As a leader, he is leading the team well.

title: ~를 바탕으로 [reul batageuro] (Based on)
short_explanation: Used to express the basis or foundation upon which something is derived.
long_explanation: The phrase '~를 바탕으로' is used to indicate that an action, decision, or creation is based on certain data, facts, or experience. It can be translated as 'on the basis of' or 'based on' in English.

examples.kr: 연구 결과를 바탕으로 새로운 약을 개발하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeongu gyeolgwareul batageuro saeroun yageul gaebalhago issseumnida.
examples.en: Based on the research results, we are developing a new medicine.

examples.kr: 경험을 바탕으로 나의 미래를 계획하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyeongheomeul batageuro naui miraereul gyehoekhago issseumnida.
examples.en: Based on my experiences, I am planning my future.

examples.kr: 이 아이디어는 과학적인 사실을 바탕으로 생각했습니다.
examples.romaji: I aideareun gwahakjeokin sasireul batageuro saenggakhaesseumnida.
examples.en: This idea is based on scientific facts.

examples.kr: 당신의 의견을 바탕으로 회의에서 얘기할 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Dangsin-ui uigeoneul batageuro, hoeuieseo yaegi-hal su isseulkka-yo?
examples.en: Can we discuss this in the meeting based on your opinion?

title: ~를 통해 [reul tonghae] (Through, by means of)
short_explanation: Used to express the medium or method by which something is done or achieved.
long_explanation: '~를 통해' is a postposition used to indicate the means, method, or channel through which an action is performed. It is equivalent to 'through', 'by means of', or 'via' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 음악을 통해 감정을 표현할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eumageul tonghae gamjeongeul pyohyeonhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I can express my emotions through music.

examples.kr: 우리는 이메일을 통해 그에게 이 메시지를 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imeireul tonghae, geu-ege i mesijireul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: We sent him the message through email.

examples.kr: 학생들은 실험을 통해 새로운 지식을 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun silheomeul tonghae saeroun jisigeul baewosseoyo.
examples.en: The students learned new knowledge through experimentation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 연습을 통해 그림 그리는 기술을 향상시켰어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeonseupeul tonghae, geurim geurineun gisuleul hyangsangshikyeosseoyo.
examples.en: She improved her painting skills through practice.

title: ~만큼 [mankeum] (As much as)
short_explanation: Used to express the amount, level, or extent equivalent to a certain standard; 'as much as', 'as...as'.
long_explanation: '~만큼 [mankeum]' is a postposition used in Korean to demonstrate equivalence in extent, amount, or level with a given reference. It is used to compare two things, implying that they have the same level or quantity. It can be interpreted as 'as much as' or 'as...as' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 그의 친구만큼 열심히 일하지 않아요, 그래서 그의 성과는 항상 작아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geu chingumankeum yeolsimhi ilhaji anhayo, geuraeseo geu seonggwaneun hangsang jagayo.
examples.en: He does not work as hard as his friend, so his performance is always weak.

examples.kr: 나는 배운 만큼 가르칩니다, 그래서 제가 알고 있는 것은 모두 다른 사람들에게 가르쳐 줄 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun baeun mankeum gareuchimnida, geuraeseo jega algo issneun geoseun modu dareun saramdeul-ege gareuchyeo jul su isseoyo.
examples.en: I teach as much as I learn, so I can teach everything I know to others.

examples.kr: 우리는 우리가 할 수 있는 만큼 최선을 다하고 있어요. 다른 사람들이 더 잘하더라도 우리는 걱정하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Urineun uriga hal su issneun mankeum choeseoneul dahago isseoyo. Dareun saramdeul-i deo jalhadeorado urineun geokjeonghaji anhayo.
examples.en: We are doing our best as much as we can. Even if others do better, we don’t worry.

examples.kr: 여행 가서 볼 수 있는 만큼 많은 것을 봤어요. 그래서 많은 추억을 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gaseo bol su issneun mankeum maneun geoseul bwasseoyo. Geuraeseo maneun chueogeul mandeuleosseoyo.
examples.en: I saw as much as I could on the trip. So I made a lot of memories.

title: ~마저 [majeo] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to express the unexpected inclusion; 'even'.
long_explanation: '~마저 [majeo]' is a postposition used in Korean to express the inclusion of someone or something that is not normally expected. It carries a sense of surprise or disbelief, similar to 'even' in English.

examples.kr: 시험이 너무 어려워서 우리 반 학생들 중에 천재인 민수마저 틀렸어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi neomu eoryeowoseo uri ban haksaengdeul jung-e cheonjaein Minsumajeo teullyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The exam was so difficult that even Minsu, a genius among the students in our class, got it wrong.

examples.kr: 집에 늦게 왔더니, 엄마마저 잠들어 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe neutge wassdeoni, eommamajeo jamdeureo isseosseoyo.
examples.en: I came home late, and even my mom was asleep.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 너무 추워서 동물원의 사자마저 숨어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga neomu chuweoseo dongmulwon-ui sajamajeo sumeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Today, the weather was so cold that even the lion at the zoo hid.

examples.kr: 그녀는 너무 유명해서 이 작은 마을 사람들마저 그녀를 알고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun neomu yumyeonghaeseo i jageun ma-eul saramdeul majeo geunyeoreul algo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is so famous that even the people in this small village know her.

title: ~못하다 [mothada] (Cannot)
short_explanation: Used to express inability or impossibility; 'cannot'.
long_explanation: '~못하다 [mothada]' is used in Korean with action verbs to indicate that the action cannot be performed. It conveys the speaker’s inability or impossibility to carry out the action.

examples.kr: 제가 솔직히 한국어를 못 하겠어요, 그래서 계속 연습하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jega soljikhi hangug-eoleul mothagesseoyo, geuraeseo gyesok yeonseukhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Honestly, I can’t speak Korean well, so I keep practicing.

examples.kr: 이 비 때문에 운동할 수가 없어요, 비가 너무 심하게 내려서 잔디밭이 미끄러워 움직일 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I biga ttaemune undonghal suga eopseoyo, biga neomu simhage naeraseo jandibat-i mikkureowo umjigil su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can’t exercise in this rain because it’s pouring so hard that the grass is slippery and I can’t move.

examples.kr: 내가 웹 개발자로서 이 문제를 해결할 수가 없어요, 코딩 실력이 부족해서 이해를 못 하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naega web gaebolja-roseo i munjeleul haegyeolhal suga eopseoyo, coding sillyeogi bujokhaeseo ihaereul mothagesseoyo.
examples.en: As a web developer, I can’t solve this problem because my coding skills are lacking.

examples.kr: 그는 금연을 못하고 있어요, 담배를 너무 좋아해서 멈출 수가 없는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geumyeon-eul mothago isseoyo, dambaeleul neomu joahaseo meomchul suga eobsneun geos gatayo.
examples.en: He can’t quit smoking because he likes cigarettes too much.

title: ~바라다 [barada] (Hope to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's hope or wish for something.
long_explanation: '~바라다 [barada]' is used after a verb stem to express a personal hope or wish. It conveys that the speaker looks forward to or wishes for a particular outcome in the future.

examples.kr: 저는 당신이 사업에서 성공하기를 바라요, 정말로 당신의 노력이 결실을 맺기를 바라요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun dangsin-i sa-eob-eseo seonggonghagil barayo, jeongmallo dangsin-ui noryeog-i gyeolsil-eul matgigil barayo.
examples.en: I hope you succeed in your business; I really hope that your efforts bear fruit.

examples.kr: 우리 모두가 건강하게 살아가기를 바라는 부모님의 마음을 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri moduga geonganghage sal-agagil baraneun bumonim-ui ma-eum-eul ihaehal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I understand the hearts of parents who wish for all of us to live healthily.

examples.kr: 교수님이 저에게 대학원에 진학하기를 바라셨어요, 그러나 저는 아직 준비가 안 돼 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gyosunim-i jeoege daehagwon-e jin-hak-hagil barasyeosseoyo, geureona jeoneun ajik junbiga an dwae isseoyo.
examples.en: The professor wished for me to go to grad school, but I'm not ready yet.

examples.kr: 난 한국어를 유창하게 말하게 될 것이라고 바라지만, 아직 많이 배워야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Nan hangug-eoreul yuchanghage malhage doel geos-irago barajiman, ajik manhi baewoya dwaeyo.
examples.en: I hope to speak Korean fluently, but I still have a lot to learn.

title: ~밖에 [bakke] (Only, nothing but)
short_explanation: Used to express limitation; 'only', 'nothing but', or 'except'.
long_explanation: '~밖에 [bakke]' is used in Korean with negative sentences to indicate that nothing else exists beyond what is mentioned. It emphasizes the limited or exclusive nature of the subject or object.

examples.kr: 나는 커피밖에 마시지 않아요, 다른 음료는 전혀 마시지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun keopibakke masiji anhayo, dareun eumryoneun jeonhyeo masiji anhayo.
examples.en: I only drink coffee; I do not drink any other beverages at all.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결할 수 있는 사람은 저밖에 없어요, 다른 사람들은 전혀 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhal su inneun sarameun jeobakke eopseoyo, dareun saramdeul-eun jeonhyeo moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I am the only one who can solve this problem; others have no idea.

examples.kr: 그는 치킨밖에 안 먹어서 다른 음식을 먹을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chikinbakke an meogeoseo dareun eumsigeul meogeul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: He eats nothing but chicken, so he can't eat other food.

examples.kr: 이게 남은 마지막 기회밖에 없어서 공부를 더 열심히 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ige nameun majimak gihoebakke eopseoseo gongbureul deo yeolsimhi haeya haeyo.
examples.en: This is the only last chance left, so I have to study harder.

title: ~본 [bon] (Having experienced)
short_explanation: Used to express that the speaker has experienced or done something.
long_explanation: '~본 [bon]' is attached to action verbs to indicate that the speaker has experienced or tried that action. It is typically used when sharing personal experiences or anecdotes.

examples.kr: 전 한국어 공부해본 사람으로서 한국어 문법을 가르치는 것이 저의 목표입니다.
examples.romaji: Jeon hangug-eo gongbuhaebon saram-euroseo hangug-eo munbeobeul gareuchineun geosi jeoui mogpyoibnida.
examples.en: As someone who has studied Korean, my goal is to teach Korean grammar.

examples.kr: 외국에서 살아본 친구가 생각보다 많아서 행복하다.
examples.romaji: Oegugeseo sarabon chingu-ga saenggakboda manhaseo haengbokhada.
examples.en: I’m happy because I have more friends who have lived abroad than I expected.

examples.kr: 코트를 샀는데, 이런 코트는 처음 입어본다.
examples.romaji: Koteureul satsneunde, ireon koteuneun cheoeum ibeobonda.
examples.en: I bought a coat, and it’s the first time I’ve worn one like this.

examples.kr: 그리스에 가본 사람이라면, 아테네는 꼭 가봐야 할 도시라고 말할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuriseue gabon saram-iramyen, ateneuneun ggok gabwaya hal dosirago malhal geosibnida.
examples.en: If you have been to Greece, you’d say that Athens is a city you must visit.

title: ~부터가 [buteoga] (Starting from)
short_explanation: Indicates that the occurrence of an action or state begins at a certain point, time, or place.
long_explanation: '~부터가 [buteoga]' combines '부터' (starting from) with the subject particle '가' to emphasize that things truly begin from that point. It is used to stress that from that moment or place onward, the state or action is in effect.

examples.kr: 나는 아침마다 강의를 듣는데, 오늘부터가 진짜 힘들음을 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achimmada gangeureul deudneunde, oneulbuteoga jinjja himdeumeul neukkyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I listen to lectures every morning, and starting from today, I really felt the hardship.

examples.kr: 사랑은 처음부터가 아니라, 서로를 이해하게 되는 순간부터 시작한다.
examples.romaji: Sarangeun cheoeumbuteoga anira, seororeul ihaehage doeneun sunganbuteo sijakanda.
examples.en: Love doesn’t start from the very beginning, but from the moment you begin to understand each other.

examples.kr: 그 일은 월요일부터가 진짜 시작이에요.
examples.romaji: Geu ireun woryoilbuteoga jinjja sijakieyo.
examples.en: That work really starts from Monday.

examples.kr: 여름 휴가는 다음 주부터가 시작인데, 이미 준비가 돼 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreum hyuganeun daeum jubuteoga sijakinde, imi junbiga dwae isseoyo.
examples.en: Summer vacation starts from next week, and I’m already prepared.

title: ~뿐이다 [ppunida] (Only, just)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'only' or 'just'.
long_explanation: '~뿐이다 [ppunida]' expresses exclusivity by stating that nothing else exists beyond what is mentioned. It is used to emphasize limitation or singularity and is typically found with a negative verb.

examples.kr: 지금 가진 돈은 오천 원뿐이다. 그래서 먹을 것을 사기엔 부족하다.
examples.romaji: Jigeum gajin doneun ocheon wonppunida. Geuraeseo meogeul geoseul sagien bujokhada.
examples.en: All I have now is five thousand won, so it’s not enough to buy food.

examples.kr: 내 친구는 너뿐이다. 그래서 네가 나를 도와주지 않으면 큰일 날 거예요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguneun neoppunida. Geuraeseo nega nareul dowajugi anheumyeon keunil nal geoyeyo.
examples.en: My only friend is you. So if you don't help me, I'm in big trouble.

examples.kr: 방 안에는 텔레비전뿐이다. 다른 가구는 아무것도 없다.
examples.romaji: Bang aneneun tellebijeonppunida. Dareun gaguneun amugeotdo eopda.
examples.en: There is only a television in the room; there is no other furniture.

examples.kr: 제 친구들 중에서, 제 이야기를 들어줄 수 있는 사람은 누나뿐이다.
examples.romaji: Je chingudeul jungeseo, je yaegireul deureojul su inneun sarameun nunappunida.
examples.en: Among my friends, only my older sister is someone who can listen to my stories.

title: ~사이에서 [saieseo] (Between)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'between' or 'among'.
long_explanation: '~사이에서 [saieseo]' is a postposition used in Korean to denote a position within a range or to specify a selection between multiple options. It is used with both tangible objects and abstract choices.

examples.kr: 어느 색깔을 고를까요? 파란색과 빨간색 사이에서 너무 힘든 선택이에요.
examples.romaji: Eoneu saekkareul goreulkka yo? Paran saekkwa bbalgan saek saieseo neomu himdeun seontaegieyo.
examples.en: Which color should I choose? It’s a tough choice between blue and red.

examples.kr: 성수동과 건대 사이에서 카페를 찾고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seongsudonggwa Geondae saieseo kape-reul chatgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm looking for a café between Seongsu-dong and Konkuk University.

examples.kr: 올해 여름동안, 둘 사이에서 결정을 내려야 합니다: 여행을 갈지 아니면 집에서 쉴지.
examples.romaji: Olhae yeoreum dongan, dul saieseo gyeoljeongeul naeryeoya hamnida: yeohaengeul galji animyeon jibeseo swilji.
examples.en: This summer, I have to decide between two options: whether to travel or to stay home and rest.

examples.kr: 10살과 15살 사이에서 가장 좋아하는 영화를 선택해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Sip sal gwa sip-oship sal saieseo gajang johahaneun yeonghwaleul seontaekhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: I had to choose my favorite movie between the ages of 10 and 15.

title: ~서야 [seoya] (Only after)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that a result is possible only if a preceding action or condition is fulfilled.
long_explanation: '~서야 [seoya]' is formed by attaching the ending '-서야' to a verb stem. It expresses that only when the preceding action is done (or the condition is met) can the subsequent result occur.

examples.kr: 공부를 열심히 해서야 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbu-reul yeolsimhi haeseoya siheom-eseo joheun jeom-su badeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only get a good score on the test after studying hard.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 돌아와서 커피를 마셔야 일을 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jib-e dorawaseoya keopi-reul masheoya ireul hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I can only work after I come home and have coffee.

examples.kr: 그녀는 강당에 도착해서야 그녀가 출연할 것임을 깨달았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gangdang-e dochakhaseoya geunyeoga chul-yeonhal geos-im-eul kkaedal-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: It was only after she arrived at the lecture hall that she realized she was going to speak.

examples.kr: 부모님에게 전화해서야 어제 일어난 사고에 대해 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-ege jeonhwahaseoya eoje il-eonan sago-e daehae alge doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: It was only after calling my parents that I learned about the accident that happened yesterday.

title: ~소서 [soseo] (Polite way to apologize for an action)
short_explanation: Used to express apology or regret in a very polite and formal manner.
long_explanation: The verb ending '~소서 [soseo]' is an archaic and formal way to apologize or express deep regret. It is typically used in formal or public settings, especially when addressing someone of higher status, to show sincere remorse and respect.

examples.kr: 내가 네게 힘들게 하였소서, 이제 나 아닌 다른 사람을 찾아가시오.
examples.romaji: Naega nege himdeulge hayeotssoseo, ije na anin dareun saram-eul chajagasyo.
examples.en: I am sorry that I have caused you hardship; now please find someone other than me.

examples.kr: 일을 까먹었소서, 너무 바빠서 정말 기억나지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Ireul kkameogeotssoseo, neomu bappaseo jeongmal gieoknazji anhatssoyo.
examples.en: I am sorry that I forgot the work; I really couldn’t remember because I was too busy.

examples.kr: 그때 과연 말을 잘못 보냈소서, 정말 죄송합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuttae gwayeon maleul jalmot bonaetssoseo, jeongmal joesonghamnida.
examples.en: I am sorry that I sent the wrong message at that time; I am truly sorry.

examples.kr: 너무 늦었소서, 지금부터 빨리 하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujeotsseoseo, jigeumbuteo ppalli hagetsseumnida.
examples.en: I am sorry that I am too late; I will do it quickly from now on.

title: ~않게 [anhge] (So as not to)
short_explanation: Used to express doing something in such a way as to prevent a certain outcome.
long_explanation: '~않게 [anhge]' is a grammatical construction formed by attaching ‘않게’ to a verb stem. It expresses the speaker’s intention to avoid or prevent an action, situation, or condition from occurring – similar to saying 'so as not to' in English.

examples.kr: 어떤 문제가 생기지 않게 미리 준비하세요.
examples.romaji: Eotteon munjega saenggiji anhge miri junbihaseyo.
examples.en: Prepare in advance so that no problems occur.

examples.kr: 아무도 당황하지 않게 시간을 정확하게 준수해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Amudo danghwanghaji anhge siganeul jeonghwakhage junsuhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: We need to keep time precisely so that no one is flustered.

examples.kr: 늦지 않게 학교에 도착하려면 일찍 출발해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Neujji anhge hakgyoe dochakharyeomyeon iljjik chulbalhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: To arrive at school on time, you should leave early.

examples.kr: 자신을 다치게 하지 않게 조심하려면 안전 지침을 따라야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jasineul dachige haji anhge josimharyeomyeon anjeon gichimeul ddaraya hamnida.
examples.en: To avoid hurting yourself, you should follow the safety guidelines.

title: ~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida] (To completely)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize that an action is done completely or to its end.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida]' attaches to a verb stem to indicate that an action is carried out completely or thoroughly, often adding a sense of finality. Depending on the context, it may express regret, surprise, or relief. This form is common in casual spoken Korean.

examples.kr: 저는 갑자기 발렌타인 데이 카드를 빠르게 만들어 버렸어요, 그런데 매우 만족스럽습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gapjagi balrentain dei kadeu-reul ppareuge mandeureo beoryeosseoyo, geureonde maeu manjokseureopseumnida.
examples.en: I suddenly made a Valentine’s Day card quickly, and I am very satisfied.

examples.kr: 객실 청소를 기다리다가 결국 나는 그냥 전부 청소해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gaesil cheongso-reul gidaridaga gyeolguk naneun geunyang jeonbu cheongsohae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: After waiting for the room to be cleaned, I ended up cleaning it all myself.

examples.kr: 나는 돼지고기를 너무 좋아해서 한 번에 다 먹어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dwaejigogireul neomu joahaseo han beone da meogeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I like pork so much that I ate it all at once.

examples.kr: 농담을 너무 심하게 해서 친구가 서운해할까봐 걱정한 나머지, 결국 죄송해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Nongdameul neomu simhage haeseo chinguga seounhae halkkabwa geokjeonghan nameoji, gyeolguk joesonghae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I made such a harsh joke that, out of worry that my friend might be hurt, I ended up apologizing.

title: ~아/어 놓다 [a/eo notda] (To have done something in advance)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action was performed ahead of time in preparation for something else.
long_explanation: '~아/어 놓다 [a/eo notda]' is used to express that an action has been done beforehand—either to prepare for a future event or to leave something in a completed state. This form is common in everyday conversation and adds nuance to your sentence structure.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 아침에 바쁠 것을 생각하고 오늘 저녁에 아침 식사를 만들어 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil achime bappeul geoseu saenggakago oneul jeonyeoge achim siksareul mandeureo noasseoyo.
examples.en: I made breakfast tonight in anticipation of being busy tomorrow morning.

examples.kr: 시험 준비를 위해 이번 주 동안 모든 강의 노트를 미리 쓰고 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom junbireul wihae ibeon ju dongan modeun gangui noteureul miri sseo noasseoyo.
examples.en: I wrote all my lecture notes in advance this week to prepare for the exam.

examples.kr: 우리는 피서 가기 전에 집안 청소를 하고 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun pisoga gagi jeone jipan cheongsoreul hago noasseoyo.
examples.en: We cleaned the house in preparation for our vacation.

examples.kr: 오늘은 친구들이 와서 미리 음식을 만들어 놓을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun chingudeuli waseo miri eumsigeul mandeureo noheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: My friends are coming over today, so I'm going to prepare the food in advance.

title: ~아/어 달라다 [a/eo dallada] (To ask for)
short_explanation: Used to make a request or ask someone to do something.
long_explanation: '~아/어 달라다 [a/eo dallada]' is a form derived from the verb '달라하다' used when requesting or asking someone to do something. It is formed by conjugating the verb into its 아/어 form and then adding 달라다.

examples.kr: 제 친구가 매우 배가 고파서, '빨리 밥을 줘 달라'고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguga maeu baega gopaseo, 'ppalli babeul jwo dalla'go malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend was very hungry, so he asked, 'Give me food quickly.'

examples.kr: 머리가 너무 아파서, '약 좀 주어 달라'고 요청했어요.
examples.romaji: Meoriga neomu apaseo, 'yak jom jueo dalla'go yocheonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had a severe headache, so I asked for some medicine.

examples.kr: 집이 너무 더워서, '에어컨 좀 틀어 달라'고 부탁했어요.
examples.romaji: Jibi neomu deoweoseo, 'eokon jom teureo dalla'go butakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: It was so hot in the house, so I asked, 'Please turn on the air conditioner.'

examples.kr: 커피가 너무 맛있어서, '한 잔만 더 줘 달라'고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Keopiga neomu masisseoseo, 'han janman deo jwo dalla'go malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: The coffee was so delicious that I asked, 'Please give me one more cup.'

title: ~아/어 대다 [a/eo daeda] (To do aimlessly)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action is done without a clear purpose or merely out of idleness.
long_explanation: '~아/어 대다 [a/eo daeda]' attaches to a verb stem to express that the action is performed aimlessly, without proper thought, or in an idle, unproductive manner.

examples.kr: 제가 그냥 막 쇼핑을 하다 대다 결국 비싼 옷을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Jega geunyang mak syoping-eul hada daeda gyeolguk bissan os-eul sass-eoyo.
examples.en: I was shopping around aimlessly and ended up buying expensive clothes.

examples.kr: 시험기간이지만 그는 그냥 책을 들여다보다 대다 시간을 다 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomgiganijiman geuneun geunyang chaeg-eul deulyeodaboda daeda sigan-eul da bonaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Even though it was exam period, he just idly looked at his books and passed the time.

examples.kr: 소리를 들으면서 그녀는 그냥 거리를 걷다 대다 음식점을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Soli reul deureumyeonseo geunyeoneun geunyang georireul geotda daeda eumsikjeom-eul nohchyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: While listening to music, she was aimlessly walking down the street and missed the restaurant.

examples.kr: 나는 지루해서 그냥 인터넷을 서핑하다 대다 알게 된 사이트에서 책을 구입했다.
examples.romaji: Naneun jiluhaeseo geunyang inteonet-eul seopinghada daeda alge doen saiteu-eseo chaeg-eul gu-ibhaetda.
examples.en: Bored, I was aimlessly surfing the internet and ended up buying a book from a site I found.

title: ~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida] (To seem, appear)
short_explanation: Used to express that something appears or seems to be a certain way.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida]' is used to indicate that something looks or appears a certain way according to the speaker's perception or judgment. It is often used to describe appearances, conditions, or states based on external observation.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 매우 행복해 보이는데, 실제로는 아마 막대한 스트레스를 받고 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun maeu haengbokhae boineunde, siljero-neun ama makdaehan seuteureseuleul badgo isseul geos gatayo.
examples.en: That woman seems very happy, but in reality, she is probably under a lot of stress.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 참 좋아 보이네요, 외출하기에 좋은 날인 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga cham joah boineyo, oechulhagi-e joheun narin geos gatayo.
examples.en: The weather seems really nice today; it appears to be a good day to go out.

examples.kr: 이 케이크는 달해 보이지만, 실제로는 그렇게 달지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Ii keikeuneun dalhae boijiman, siljero-neun geureoke dalji anhayo.
examples.en: This cake seems sweet, but it isn’t actually that sweet.

examples.kr: 나는 피곤해 보인다고 친구가 말했어요, 하지만 저는 그렇게 느낀 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pigonhae boindago chinguga malhaesseoyo, hajiman jeoneun geureoke neukkin jeogi eobseoyo.
examples.en: My friend said I looked tired, but I’ve never felt that way.

title: ~아/어 서는 [a/eo seoneun] (Although)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast or contrary expectation; 'although' or 'but'.
long_explanation: '~아/어 서는 [a/eo seoneun]' is used to present a situation that contrasts with or contradicts an expectation. It can be translated as 'although' or 'but' and highlights an unexpected or contrary fact.

examples.kr: 날씨가 춥다고 해서는 외출을 안 했는데, 실제로는 그리 춥지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chubdago haeseoneun oechuleul an haenneunde, siljero-neun geuri chubji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although they said it was cold, I didn’t go out; in fact, it wasn’t that cold.

examples.kr: 헬스장에 자주 가서는 운동을 열심히 했는데, 체중은 거의 줄지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Helthjange jaju gaseoneun undongeul yeolsimhi haenneunde, chejungeun geojeul julji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although I went to the gym frequently and worked out hard, my weight barely decreased.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부해서는 시험을 잘 보려고 했는데, 결과는 좋지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaseoneun siheomeul jal boryeogo haenneunde, gyulegwaneun joaji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although I studied hard to do well on the exam, the result wasn’t good.

examples.kr: 저는 열심히 외워서는 공연 때 잘 했다고 생각했는데, 실수를 많이 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeolsimhi weowoseoneun gongyeon ttae jal haetdago saenggakhaenneunde, silsureul mani haesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I memorized it thoroughly and thought I did well during the performance, I ended up making many mistakes.

title: ~아/어야만 [a/eoyaman] (Only if/when)
short_explanation: Used to express a condition that only if/when something happens, something else will or can occur.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어야만' is a conditional form in Korean that expresses the idea that only if/when a certain condition is satisfied can an expected result occur. This grammar point indicates that an action or state is contingent on a condition being fulfilled; without that condition, the action or state is impossible. It is often used with potential or hypothetical situations.
formation: Verb + 아/어야만 (Depending on the final vowel of the verb stem)

examples.kr: 고등학교를 졸업해야만 대학교에 들어갈 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Godeunghakgyoreul joreobhaeyaman daehakgyoe deuleogal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only go to university if you graduate from high school.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 위해 꼭 티켓을 예약해야만 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwareul wihae ggok tikeseul yeyakhaeyaman bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only watch that movie if you book the tickets in advance.

examples.kr: 목표를 이루려면 하루하루 열심히 일해야만 해요.
examples.romaji: Mokpyoreul iruryeomyeon haruharu yeolsimhi ilhaeyaman haeyo.
examples.en: In order to achieve your goal, you have to work hard every day.

examples.kr: 거기에 가려면 버스를 타야만 해요, 지하철로는 갈 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geogie garyeomyeon beoseureul taya haeyaman haeyo, jihacheoroneun gal su eopsseoyo.
examples.en: To get there, you have to take a bus; it's not possible to go by subway.

title: ~아/어지다 [a/eojida] (To become)
short_explanation: Used to express a change of state, meaning 'to become'.
long_explanation: '~아/어지다' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate a change in state, condition, or emotion—essentially, 'to become'. The ending is chosen based on the vowel in the preceding syllable (use '아지다' after ㅏ or ㅗ, and '어지다' for all other vowels). It is often used to show a transition from one state to another.

examples.kr: 날씨가 갑자기 추워져서 난로를 켜야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga gapjagi chuweojyeoseo nanroleul kyeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather suddenly became cold, so I had to turn on the heater.

examples.kr: 작년에는 일을 너무 많이 해서 피곤해서 쉴 시간이 없어져서 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jaknyeoneun ireul neomu manihaseo pigonhaeseo swil sigan-i eobseojyeoseo himdeureoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Last year, I worked so much that I became tired and had no time to rest, so it was tough.

examples.kr: 친구가 바빠지니까 자주 만날 수 없게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga bappajinikkaji jaju mannal su eobge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Since my friend became busy, we couldn't meet as often.

examples.kr: 음식이 너무 많아져서 한 번에 다 먹을 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigi neomu manhajyeoseo han beone da meogeul su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: The food became so abundant that I couldn't eat it all at once.

title: ~았/었 던 [at/eot deon] (Past descriptive)
short_explanation: Used to describe past events or situations from the speaker's memory.
long_explanation: '~았/었 던' is a past descriptive form in Korean used to recall an event, person, or situation that occurred in the past. It is commonly attached to a verb (forming '보던') when modifying a noun and expresses a past state or memory from the speaker’s perspective.
formation: Verb in past tense (~았/었) + 던 (attached before a noun)

examples.kr: 제가 어릴 때 즐겨 보던 애니메이션 쇼를 어제 다시 보았어요, 많은 추억이 떠올랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoril ttae jeulgyeo bodon aenimeisyeon syoreul eoje dasi boasseoyo, manheun chueogi tteooreosseoyo.
examples.en: I watched the animation show I used to enjoy as a kid again yesterday, and many memories came flooding back.

examples.kr: 그는 5년 전에 만났던 친구와 오랜만에 다시 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun 5nyeon jeone mannatdeon chinguwa oraenman-e dasi mannatseoyo.
examples.en: He met a friend he had met 5 years ago after a long time.

examples.kr: 여름에 가봤던 해변에 다시 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreum-e gabwatdeon haebyeone dasi gago sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to go back to the beach I visited in the summer.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 만났던 친구들과 지금도 친하게 지내요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoeso mannatdeon chingudeulgwa jigeumdo chinhage jinaeyo.
examples.en: I am still close with the friends I met at school.

title: ~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon jokgetda] (Wish something had happened)
short_explanation: Used to express a wish or hope that something had occurred in the past.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 좋겠다' is a grammar construction in Korean that expresses a speaker's wish or regret about a past event that did not occur. By combining a verb in the past tense with '으면 좋겠다', it conveys a longing for a different past outcome.

examples.kr: 회사에 보고하러 갔었으면 좋겠다, 그러면 지금 이렇지 않았을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Hoesae bogoharerogasseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureomyeon jigeum ireotji anhasseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had gone to report to the company; then I wouldn't be like this now.

examples.kr: 당신을 더 일찍 알았었으면 좋겠다, 그렇게 되면 많은 문제를 피할 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Dangsineul deo iljjik arasseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureohge doemyeon manheun munjeleul pihal su isseosseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had known you sooner; then I could have avoided many problems.

examples.kr: 난 그날 그를 따랐었으면 좋겠다, 그러면 어떤 경험을 할 수 있었을까?
examples.romaji: Nan geunal geuleul ttaratseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureomyeon eoddeon gyeongheomeul hal su isseosseulkka?
examples.en: I wish I had followed him that day—what kind of experience would I have had?

examples.kr: 더 많은 연습을 했었으면 좋겠다, 그래야 내 성과가 더욱 개선될 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Deo manheun yeonseubeul haesseosseumyeon jokgetda, geuraeya nae seonggwaga deouk gaeseondwaesseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had practiced more, then my performance could have improved even further.
